There were those who predicted dire consequences for the colony as it then was. The same is true today. However, I venture to say that whereas rational argument was put forward in those days what we are seeing today is, as I said earlier, downright scaremongering and deliberate lies, distortions and misinformation. As polling day approaches, the predictions of doom and destruction—of the end of the Australian political and social way of life as we know it—have become even more bizarre and more outrageous. It seems that no lie and no fanciful prediction is too outrageous to make if it will help to defeat the referendum. Deliberate scaremongering rather than reasoned debate has become the monarchists' main strategy as polling day approaches.

I want to refute some of those false and misleading arguments advanced by those associated with the no case. Firstly, let me deal with that discredited argument, put for ward by Kerry Jones initially and still being argued by people such as Sir David Smith—that the Queen is not really our head of state; that the Governor-General is our head of state. As we know, that is simply not true. Many on the monarchists' side understand that but there are those such as Sir David Smith who are still advancing it. One wonders why. Why do they resort to such lies and such misinformation to support their case? I ask the question: who does Sir David Smith believe invested him with his knighthood? Who was responsible for his knighthood? It was our head of state, the Queen. Who is opening the Olympic Games? It should be our head of state, the Queen, according to Olympic tradition. But because she is the Queen of England, the Olympic committee for the first time has approved someone other than a head of state—a Prime Minister—to open the Olympic Games. Special arrangements have had to be made for Australia because of this ridiculous situation we have whereby our head of state is not an Australian.

I interpose here to note that the Prime Minister, avowed monarchist as he is, does not mind taking the job on, accepting the glory and accepting the opportunity to appear on the world stage by opening the Olympics. It is clear that he can be flexible with respect to our constitutional arrangements when it suits him. For instance, he has put forward his own preamble which, following negotiations with the Democrats, is now to go forward to the people on the same day in the referendum. We are supporting that change in the preamble. Albeit a second-best effort, it does represent a modernising of the preamble attached to the Constitution. It is bringing Australia up to date by recognising such things as a prior relationship between the Aboriginals and this continent. The Prime Minister is prepared to modernise the Constitution in that respect, but he is not prepared to do what is fundamentally important and necessary: that is, to allow an Australian to become our head of state.
Another argument being advanced is that a constitutional monarchy is better than a republic. I noted an article in the paper today by Sir James Hardy who stated this:
As you can imagine, as a `knight of the realm', I will be voting for the status quo.

The word president scares me. Save for the USA, France and the recent President Mandela of South Africa, most republics of the world, whether in central and South America, Asia, Africa or eastern Europe, appear to be pretty unhappy regimes.
Monarchies on the other hand, for example, Japan, Thailand, Belgium, Holland and the Nordic countries, seem far more settled.

This argument is advanced by people on the monarchists' side that constitutional monarchies are good, republics are bad. That again is scaremongering and it is a distortion of history. Indeed, many republics have come about because of the problems of monarchies. Despotic, dynastic, aristocratic rulers in many countries have been replaced by republican regimes or governments. Some have worked, some have not. The great democracies of the world—for instance the United States and France—demonstrate that republics can work. Equally there have been others that have not. Such a simplistic argument is not only wrong, it also demeans the entire debate because it ignores the many influences that impact upon systems of government.

This argument has reached its most extreme form in the views expressed by some members of the government who refer to the Weimar Republic in Germany and how that was supposed to have led to the rise of Hitler. They suggest that moving to an Australian head of state will somehow bring doom and destruction and a dictator in as president. Such a view is insulting to the intelligence of the Australian people. It suggests that we cannot cope with change, even though we have done so consistently throughout the last 100 years. It demonstrates the paucity of the monarchists' case.

It also ignores particularly the history of England itself. The history of the British monarchy, even in this century, has not been without great controversy. There are those, for instance, such as Geoffrey Blainey, the noted historian, and Bronwyn Bishop, a government minister, who claim that having the Queen of England is a guarantee of stability. If that is the case, I invite them to look, for instance, at the constitutional history of England. They only have to go back, as I have pointed out before, to 1936 and what happened then when the King of England, Edward VIII, became king upon the death of his father and was ultimately forced to abdicate his office. He was never crowned. Why? Because he wanted to marry a divorced American woman, Wallis Simpson, and the British parliament, the political leaders of the day and even the Church of England said to Edward VIII, `You cannot. You will have to choose between the throne and marriage to a divorced woman.' Ultimately he was forced to abdicate. That crisis went on for an entire year in England. Whilst it may now be distant in the memories of people—certainly I was not alive then—you only have to read the history to find out that the monarchy in England came very close to collapse at that time.

There are two points to note—firstly, England itself, the home of the constitutional monarchy and the Westminster system, has not been free of its own constitutional upheaval. Secondly, and I think more importantly, at that time Australia had to sit by and watch from the sideline while others in another country debated and argued about who would be the head of state of England and therefore the head of state of Australia. It is not scaremongering to suggest that this situation might actually arise in the not too distant future if Charles III becomes the King of England.
It is also important to note some features of the position of the monarch in England. Geoffrey Blainey recently said:
. . . under the present system the Prime Minister of Australia cannot dismiss the head of state. In short, the Prime Minister cannot dismiss the Queen.

Well, that is true in Australia. But, interestingly, it is not true in England. In England, the monarch is not above the rule or the law of parliament. Again, the history of England shows that. One can go back to Magna Carta, but more particularly to the Act of Settlement of 1701, which sets out and confines the role of the monarch and the rules of succession of the English monarch. As the noted philosopher Walter Bagehot said in 1867, even the Queen is not above the laws of parliament. He stated:
The Queen cannot exercise the power of veto over bills put forward by the parliament. She must sign her own death warrant if the two houses unanimously send it up to her.

Why do I resort to this historical argument? Because it demonstrates that in England the Queen has a different status compared to the situation in Australia; that is, the parliament itself can ultimately, if it so decides, abolish the monarchy. So anyone who suggests that somehow the existence of a constitutional monarchy is the guarantee of continuous stable government in this country is really distorting constitutional law and historical fact.

I go back to Sir James Hardy's comments earlier about the supposed stability of monarchies around the world. Even if one accepts, as I do, that countries such as Belgium, Denmark, Japan today and a number of others that have monarchies, or indeed constitutional monarchies, are stable countries, there is one interesting feature about all of those monarchies. Each one of those countries, except for the countries inside the British Commonwealth, have their own head of state. The King and Queen of Belgium are Belgians. The monarch of Denmark is a Dane. In Australia, the head of state is not an Australian. It is Queen Elizabeth II, an Englishwoman. I find it ironic that, as was proved recently by the High Court, Australians need to be Australian citizens and renounce citizenship to another country to be members of this parliament and ultimately become Prime Minister. The Queen and members of the royal family can never aspire to that, because they are not Australian citizens. Ironically, while an Australian can become a member of parliament, can become prime minister or can hold public office in this country as an Australian citizen, that same person cannot currently become our head of state. That is the change we need on 6 November.

talk.start.para: —I commend Senator Forshaw on his speech. As a member of the yes committee, I have been absolutely astounded by some of the scaremongering and the inappropriate tactics that have been used and have emanated from the no campaign. Indeed, yesterday I attended a Property Council of Australia function, a debate involving the heads of the yes and no committees, and I was astounded to hear Kerry Jones's retort to Malcolm Turnbull when he said that our head of state was a foreigner and lived overseas. She suggested that Sir William Deane might be offended to be described as a foreigner. This persistence that our head of state is somehow located in Australia, is an Australian and living in the Governor-General's quarters is quite extraordinary. Similarly, I wish to correct a statement that was made in public yesterday by Ms Jones. She suggested that eminent lawyer George Winterton had critiqued the model and suggested it had flaws—that is true—and that he would not be voting for this model. That is untrue. I think it is completely outrageous that that was put on record at such a prominent function in Sydney yesterday.

speech.para: Today I wish to refer to two matters. The first is the issue of genetic privacy. Actually, before that I will put on record the second matter. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to two misrepresentations in this place by Senator Richard Alston on 30 September 1999. Both these misrepresentations were made during the minister's speech to the notice of motion moved jointly by myself and Senator Bishop regarding the Internet censorship legislation. The first misrepresentation relates to the following statement made during that debate by the minister. He said:
The only people who raised it—
That is, Internet censorship legislation—-
with me on that visit were Yahoo who thought it was a good idea.
In fact, Yahoo made statements contradicting this when the minister first suggested that they supported the government's Internet censorship legislation.
The following quote from Mr Tony Faure, the general manager of Yahoo Australia, was carried by the Australian Personal Computer News Wire on 7 June 1999. I quote:
Yahoo Vice-President Heather Killen spoke to the minister. (However), as a matter of interest, neither she or the company endorsed it or not endorsed it.
Another quote from the same man, Tony Faure, confirmed this. He said:
Let me tell anyone who might be under the impression that we endorse the bill that we certainly do not.

The second misrepresentation relates to the position of Lotus and its CEO, Jeff Papows. The minister quoted Mr Papows as having endorsed content regulation. The minister made the following statement to the Senate:
His—
Meaning Jeff Papows'-
answer was,`Industry has no issue with online content regulation. The industry endorses content regulation.'
Well, Mr Acting Deputy President, this has been contradicted by Mr Bryan Simmons, Lotus Vice-President of Worldwide Corporate Communications, who has said that the company did not:
`in any way regulate the distribution methods used by our customers based on the content of the material, or suggest or dictate these to governments.'
Bryan Simmons went on to add the following:
Jeff's comments were meant only to communicate deference to the government's sphere of sovereignty, not support any government's particular policies.

I think these are serious matters that need a response as a matter of urgency from the minister. It has been widely debated online and of course in various Internet industry circles, the fact that the minister has repeatedly now not only contradicted or misrepresented statements made by company officials, but that he has done so at least on one occasion in this place and most recently, of course, in the debate that we had on that joint notice of motion.

The second matter I wish to refer to today is essentially to update the Senate on the ongoing debate about genetic privacy and non-discrimination. Last year I introduced the Genetic Privacy and Non-Discrimination Bill. This was introduced, if you like, as a primer for debate about the introduction of genetic technology into our community. To date this technology has been introduced without the kind of community debate that every new technology should get. Of course, the bill was quite rightly referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and a report was tabled on 30 March this year.

I believe the report was a significant outcome, certainly for the debate but legislatively, because it showed the diversity of views in the broader community and the breadth of application of this new technology to our lives. Perhaps even better, the government has acknowledged the need to examine genetic discrimination as a new form of discrimination in Australia. The Attorney-General has also instructed the Privacy Commissioner to undertake a review of health information practices and the government has initiated the links with other states and territories to discuss genetic privacy. These are welcome developments. However, the decision by this government to adopt a self-regulatory approach to privacy generally through the so-called light touch regulation and the limited scope of the Privacy Commissioner's health information review, which will not consider all genetic information, leaves us with some stark choices in Australia. The government's generic privacy approach is really directed to personal information privacy and protects only the privacy of the information. My proposal instead attaches privacy and due process to the genetic sample collected from the individual and makes sure its privacy is intimately linked with consent, with authorisation, ownership and genetic counselling. Perhaps the most concerning aspect of the government's approach is that because not all genetic information is health information, there is a great likelihood that different self-regulating sectors will develop inconsistent privacy codes. For example, an insurance company collecting non-health genetic information might apply a different standard from an employer and a different standard again from a bank and a hospital or a local doctor.

Under the government's proposal there is a very great chance different standards will apply and that is ironic, because that was the reason given by this government initially for not introducing a privacy regime.

Of course, the other claim we saw in submissions to the committee was that legislation was not necessary. I certainly presented a range of examples in the report to the committee on behalf of the Democrats, including a United States survey of access to stored heel prick screening blood samples by third parties which showed a willingness to release the cards to insurance companies, employers and law enforcement agencies, quite often just because they were asked for the information.

This concern was confirmed in a submission which dealt with the same issue in Australia, where heel prick samples were taken and stored. The processes followed by that institution holding the cards were not satisfactory and highlighted the need for regulation so that we can all be sure that our genetic information is safe.

A recent survey of quality assurance in genetic testing laboratories just adds to the weight of evidence that we need effective regulation. This survey was conducted by Margaret McGovern and others from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York and the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. They surveyed laboratories conducting genetic tests to determine what tests were being done and the standards which were being applied. Their findings are reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association. They were quite a major surprise and strongly reinforced how urgently we need to review genetic technology to make sure we are getting only benefits from this technology.

The survey found that the number of genetic tests were increasing at a rate of approximately 30 per cent per year over 1994, 1995 and 1996. Some 70 per cent offered genetic counselling through a counsellor employed by the laboratory, or through an affiliation of the laboratory, which left 30 per cent with no access to genetic counselling. In 45 per cent of the laboratories, some form of informed consent was required and 69 per cent had a written confidentiality policy. Sadly, this means that more than half the laboratories did not require some form of informed consent and approximately 30 per cent had no written privacy policy.

Perhaps the most chilling finding was that only six per cent of laboratories which required the informed consent of the already low number would reject a sample if it did not have the informed consent. Clearly, a preference was shown for people who were not involved in signing away or being involved in a privacy regime.

The authors concluded these findings showed a variable set of policies for counselling, privacy and informed consent. They also said that the low levels of informed consent were troubling because of the potential for pre-symptomatic and predisposition testing and that this posed `a substantial risk to patients in terms of genetic discrimination'.

I accept that these figures are from the United States and of course that the Australian experience is likely to be different because of our different health systems and the way our health systems operate. Despite this, this report is concerning and it confirms that we need to have similar studies in Australia. Without these studies, we should apply the precautionary principle and we should be adopting regulatory measures which will make sure that the basics of genetic technology are satisfied. This includes, at the minimum, an informed consent, privacy and counselling. These are issues that are being dealt with in the Genetic Privacy and Non-Discrimination Bill that we have tabled and merely touched on or outside the scope of the government's self-regulatory approach.

I also note the release by the National Health and Medical Research Council of its latest draft guidelines under section 95 of the Privacy Act for privacy in research. This is a welcome review. However, we need to recognise that these guidelines have limited application under the Privacy Act and under the law and that the Privacy Act itself has quite a limited operation. Effectively the Privacy Act and these guidelines only apply to Commonwealth agencies and any researchers using information for research provided by the Commonwealth. The NHMRC claims these guidelines provide a framework for all research—that is certainly true—but they do not provide enforceable laws for most research institutions in Australia, where there is effectively no regulation.

Quoting the press release from the NHMRC from 17 August this year, when these guidelines were first released, it sums up my views entirely and confirms the need for legislation which deals comprehensively with genetic privacy and non-discrimination. The press release reads:
Privacy is a basic human right. Australians expect their rights to be recognised and protected.
I agree whole-heartedly. I look forward to seeing effective legislation to guarantee that recognition and protection.

talk.start.para: —I rise today in this debate to make reference to a very important report which was prepared by the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector. The title of the report is Fair Market or Market Failure? . I particularly want to underline some of the comments made by my Democrat colleague Senator Andrew Murray in his minority report as part of the major report. I want to put within the context of the comments of Senator Murray some disturbing trends in fresh fruit and vegetable marketing in Brisbane, particularly the wholesale markets at Rocklea. I refer to the decline in the amount of fruit and vegies going through that market and in some ways a crisis in the wholesale market in those central markets in Brisbane.

speech.para: What I want to do is show that the things that Senator Murray says in his minority report to the major report in fact reinforce claims that were made to me by wholesalers at those markets. I have not yet been able to completely verify those claims, but I think they are so serious that in fact they ought to be reported here and they should be taken very seriously indeed.

A couple of weeks ago I visited the Brisbane markets at the request of Mark Griffiths and a number of other wholesalers who met with me for a couple of hours. They raised serious questions about market distortions in both the wholesale as well as the retail market for fresh fruit and vegetables in Queensland.

But let me return for a moment to the joint committee report, Fair Market or Market Failure?. In that report Senator Murray made some comments, particularly under the heading `A Viable Independent Retail Sector', and I quote some of his remarks:

In designing competition policy we have to determine a set of values and principles which should guide our laws and behaviour. First amongst these should be the recognition that monopolies or oligopolies inherently contain within them a capacity for the abuse of market power, and should usually be resisted where they emerge, or monitored where they already exist. Therefore a situation such as we have in the Australian supermarket industry, where an oligopoly is present, has to be acted upon.
Secondly, we must acknowledge that a viable and thriving independent sector in the retail industry is desirable of itself and that it has an economic and social value that should not be lost.

In retailing, this independent sector is most at threat in Australia in the supermarket sector, where the critical mass essential to its survival is under threat. However, the trend is also emerging in non-supermarket retail sectors, and that problem needs to be addressed to prevent such crises emerging there too.
Certainly I would underline what Senator Murray said in that minority report in relation to the Brisbane fruit and vegetable market.

Senator Murray made a recommendation that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission be required to include in its considerations this particular aspect, and that is to ensure the preservation of a viable independent sector in retailing.

The people that I spoke to at the Brisbane markets made some very serious claims about that threat, a threat not only to the retail sector in the marketing of fruit and vegetables, but also in the wholesale sector. Their experience confirms that the area of retailing is in fact under serious threat. In the evidence given to me, the following claims were made: first, that fruit and vegetable prices have always been determined by supply and demand. Secondly, penetration of the market by the major supermarkets has distorted market processes and depressed returns to growers.

Supermarket dominance has the following effects: first, the distortion of prices—the depression of prices by not participating on a daily basis in the marketplace on many selected lines, hence giving poor returns to farmers and then farmers are lost to the industry. Secondly, the dislocation of the central business districts in many small to medium country towns. Thirdly, gluts are not resolved by naturally occurring market forces and if they are ever cleared it is because of direct buying with selected growers. These claims need to be verified, but they are serious and they should be tested further.
Senator Murray also commented on the issue of predatory pricing and trading hours. Again I would like to quote from the report that he made. He said this about predatory pricing:
The Committee received significant evidence as to the difficulty in bringing a successful action under section 46, (which deals with misusing market power) for predatory pricing.
That is section 46 of the Trade Practices Act. Senator Murray continued:

Witnesses consistently complained of the difficulty in proving predatory pricing. . . I would like to reiterate the comments of Professor Allan Fels, Chairman of the ACCC, on the merits of the reversed onus of proof test. Professor Fels said:

`There may be scope for some further strengthening of section 46 in terms of that kind of thing; that, if the effect can be shown, then there is a reverse onus of proof on purpose. That would essentially keep it to purpose. There is a problem at the moment with the test in that the Commission or private litigants have to embark upon a cops and robbers type search for purpose in particular cases. They are just not going to succeed in that, even though one has a fair idea that the purpose is anti-competitive. So there is a case for reversing the onus without departing from the underlying notion that, in the end, it would be a purpose test.'

It is interesting that Senator Murray, again in his minority report, recommended along the lines suggested by Professor Fels that the Trade Practices Act should be revisited and section 46 should indeed be strengthened so that a reverse onus of proof test should be possible.

On the issue of trading hours, Senator Murray also had comments to make and I must say that many of the comments of Senator Murray were supported by the major report, but were not put in as strong terms as those of Senator Murray. He says:

The Committee received a substantial amount of evidence in relation to the deregulation of trading hours. This issue has played a major role in making the independent sector vulnerable and less viable. The theme was that small independent retailers are being pushed out of the grocery retailing market as the majors extend their trading hours and the public gravitate towards the majors and away from small independents.
What is more, the Majors have been leaders in the lobbying campaign for deregulated trading hours, expressed at its most extreme by the push for twenty-four hour seven day trading.
There is also a considerable social impact to the extent that owner/operators of independent grocers are forced to maintain longer hours just to keep up with the major retailers.
State governments need to keep a much greater account of the social and economic impacts of deregulated trading hours than has previously occurred.

In his report Senator Murray commends the Western Australian state government as having been able to regulate the market much more to the satisfaction of all and certainly to the enhancement of competition in that state.

With regard to the Brisbane markets, evidence was given that the effects of predatory pricing and longer trading hours have in fact been detrimental. The wholesalers told me in a number of bits of evidence that they gave me that these are very serious issues. They claimed that the supermarkets were deliberate in the actions they had taken. The wholesalers at the markets said that deregulation of trading hours, where small and family owned businesses cannot stay open because of the expense, seems to be a deliberate strategy by the major supermarkets.

On predatory pricing, I was told that prices change from store to store to suit the competition they face. That is, in a shopping centre where there is not an individually owned fruit shop or butcher et cetera, the prices will be high, but where there are small competitors, then Coles and Woolworths will in fact take on those small retailers but, interestingly enough, they do not take on each other. The claim was made to me that this is evidence of collusion.

So these are issues that I think underline the importance of the Fair Market or Market Failure? report. It is about time we heard the government's response to that report, because it is a very urgent matter indeed.

Claims were also made to me by wholesalers at the Brisbane markets that the bypassing of the central market in Brisbane by the major supermarket chains is also detrimental to fair trading as it is to the farmers who become the victims, very often, in a kind of a war between farmers and the major supermarkets. The evidence given to me, if I could just quote from this document, is that bypassing central markets, by dealing directly with farmers for fruit and vegetables, in a lot of cases means that growers send less desirable size produce and then have it rejected. This practice gives false prices and generally holds market prices down.

They go on to say that the practice of orchestrating gluts in the market means two things: supermarkets make an exorbitant profit when they are able to manipulate the market in this way. Also, they do not help to reduce oversupply by keeping market price low; rather, the index they use for growers is based on market averages and then they manipulate those averages.

These are some of the issues that were presented to me in underlining the importance of the report which was made by the joint committee. The claim also was made that there is a lot of vertical integration going on. Growers have been encouraged to expand and absorb smaller farms and the claim was that this is because it is much easier to manipulate the fewer and fewer growers and make them produce to the specifications of the supermarket, but always at the growers' expense. The claim was that there is a feeling of helplessness, both on the part of wholesalers and of farmers, as the supermarkets become more and more dominant. The wholesalers felt they were getting little help from government and that the supermarkets dominate all who come under their influence, including landlords and suppliers, et cetera.

I want to underline—I notice I am running out of time and I will perhaps need to return to this—that I tried to get some confirmation of what has been happening. I approached Trevor Brewer from Market Information Systems, which operates out of the Brisbane markets, and I will seek from him more of the statistical evidence to show one way or the other what is happening, but as yet I have not been able to get that evidence.

I urge the government to respond to the joint committee report, Fair Market or Market Failure?, as soon as possible and I commend my colleague Andrew Murray on the excellence of the minority report that he tabled as part of the major study.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some remarks today about the role of the Senate under the proposed change to a republic, which will be voted on by our fellow citizens on 6 November. It is not a matter that has been discussed in the media. I have tried to alert the media to the significant change to the role of the Senate which is involved in the republican model that is to be put to the people, but as Professor Flint was reported as saying in this morning's press, it is very difficult to have any argument in relation to the referendum put that supports the no case in most of Australia's major metropolitan daily newspapers. That is very unfortunate, but for those of us who feel strongly that the model that is proposed is a seriously flawed one, at best it means that we have to continue to put our case where we can.

speech.para: In relation to the wiping out of the role of the Senate in this republican model, there is no better place to discuss that impact of the flawed republican model than here in one of the greatest political and democratic institutions ever put on this earth—a great Australian institution, a great part of Australia's very own Australian-designed and democratically voted upon institutions, put in place by our great founding fathers. That institution, the Senate, represents the states. In its design by our founding fathers and in its years of operation ever since and coming up to its centenary, it has been able to ensure a different plurality, a different representation of the Australian people's democratic rights. It has significant powers to overturn decisions of governments, to overturn decisions of the House of Representatives, and to do so on a basis that represents the states of Australia with equal numbers—a very powerful institution with significant powers.

Yet when we come to the republican model, we find that senators will indeed have a right to vote on a nomination to be made by the Prime Minister and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition in the other place. We will have the privilege of walking across to the other chamber and casting our votes—not really a vote in the way most people would expect. Most would expect that a democratic vote in relation to electing a President would perhaps be a choice of candidates, as in most other elections in the free world, but this is effectively a rubber-stamp of a decision that has been made by two politicians—specifically the Prime Minister and, through the seconding of the motion, the Leader of the Opposition. So, in fact, it is a decision of two politicians, who for their own political power rely on as little as 50 per cent plus one of the votes in either their caucus or party room for their own power.

Let us consider what will happen when it comes to the very important issue of the role of head of state under the proposed new constitution—and that is what it will be; you cannot say it is the existing constitution because it will have 69 changes to it. It will be a new constitution, with very little resemblance to the old one. It will be a new Australian political system. Under that proposal the dismissal provisions provide something unique in the free world—that the Prime Minister can sack the President in writing and effectively in secret. The only constraint on a Prime Minister dismissing the President or head of state is a political constraint.

To home in on that point we need to understand that the new head of state will derive his or her power from that vote I referred to earlier—from a vote of two-thirds of the politicians sitting at any one time in the Australian parliament; that is, the two houses, the House of Representatives and the Senate. That is how the president derives his or her power. That power is limited by the fact that the person has as their most important role—forgetting all the other roles that are performed by either the Governor-General now or the President as would occur if the case gets up in November—that of umpire in any political or constitutional crisis in Australia. The head of state will be an independent umpire who can seek to resolve a political or constitutional crisis, ensure that Australia's government and democratic institutions move on and that the best interests of the people prevail.

In that case, you have a president who, having to make a crucial decision at a time of crisis within our political or constitutional systems, has hanging over his or her head the threat of dismissal. If we want to use the umpire analogy on a field of play, the umpire who is contemplating raising the whistle to his or her mouth would have the threat hanging over his or her head that he or she would be sacked or dismissed unilaterally before he or she has a chance to blow air through that whistle.

Therein lies one of the significant problems of the republican model. The only constraint on the Prime Minister from dismissing that President before he or she blows the whistle is the threat to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister get a motion moved by the House of Representatives. This is the nub of the issue that I want to raise here today—it is not the Australian Parliament, it is the House of Representatives, because the Senate has no say in this dismissal. It is a point that has not been featured in any article that I have been able to find in any major metropolitan newspaper. For probably only the second time in nearly 100 years where a major decision needs to be taken by the Australian Parliament, the Senate is rubbed out unilaterally. The Senate has no say. Senators elected by the millions of Australians who democratically go along and vote every three years have no say in this crucial decision.

So what the Prime Minister needs to do is contemplate whether he can get a majority in his party room to support that decision. So he needs 50 per cent plus one in his party room—or her party room when we have a female prime minister, which I am sure will occur at some stage, I hope during my lifetime. I hope it is a Liberal too, Senator Coonan. He or she will need to know that he or she has 50 per cent plus one in their party room because that is how prime ministers have their jobs. As Mr Hawke and Mr Keating and previous prime ministers know, if they do not have 50 per cent plus one in their party room, they are not the prime minister.

So the only political constraint on a prime minister exercising his power to unilaterally—and, effectively, secretly in the first instance—dismiss the president, the umpire, is in fact that constraint. I say to you that that is the only time—with one exception and that exception is a very weak one which I will go into later—when the Australian Parliament has been asked to make a decision, but only the House of Representatives actually does it. I say that that is an overturning of the whole foundation of Australia's federation. I put it to the Senate—and it is probably now a gratuitous argument, because we are a great federation and we are a great federation because our founding fathers gave us such a fantastic constitution and such powerful institutions as the Senate—that had the founding fathers proposed or had proposed to them that our head of state be elected by two-thirds of the politicians, but dismissed by potentially 23 per cent of the parliament—which is all that the Prime Minister requires—and that the Senate would have no say in that dismissal, then the founding fathers would not have had their constitution and the federation supported by the Australian people. There is no way in the world that the people of Western Australia, Tasmania, South Australia or Queensland would have voted as they did nearly 100 years ago to form a federation if the Senate, which was so crucial to bringing the smaller, outlying, less populous states into the federation in the first place, would not have had a say in the dismissal.

I said earlier that there has been only one other example that I can find—and I am happy for the yes case to find another example—where that applies in the Australian constitution or our history. That relates to referendums themselves. Section 128 of the Constitution provides that if one house of the parliament passes a bill for an act for a referendum, it is passed twice within a statutory time—I think it is a three-month period in between—and the other house fails to pass it, then the Governor-General can refer those matters to the people at a referendum.

So, hypothetically, if the House of Representatives were to pass some referendum proposals twice, the Senate rejected them, and the House of Representatives passed them again three months later, the government of the day could put to the Governor-General that those matters be put, as happened in 1974. The result, of course, was that those proposals went down. I think that probably reflects what has happened in Australian constitutional history and the history of referendums—that unless there is broad bipartisan support, referendums do not usually get up.

Section 128 says that one house of parliament can pass a referendum proposal twice, when the other place does not. Why is the Senate being taken out of that process? Although it is quite explicit in section 128 that one house can pass a measure twice and have it put to the people, when that was sought to be practised in 1914 when the Senate twice passed two proposals with the statutory required time in between, the then Governor-General, Sir Ronald Munro Ferguson, on the advice of his ministers, refused to put the proposal to the people.

One would suspect that if the Senate made a proposal, just as the House of Representatives did in 1974, and the other place did not support it, it probably would not have got up anyway. But the practice in Australia now is that the House of Representatives can pass measures twice and have them put to the people and historically the Senate cannot. That is the only other case we can find where the Senate is not part of the powers of the Australian Parliament.

So here we have a fundamental change to Australia's system of government. The reality is that a head of state will have his or her power base formed by a vote—not a selective ballot; no more than one name will be put forward. We will not have any choice in that; the name of the candidate will emerge through a process that I have said is less transparent than that which applies in the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and less transparent than that which applies in the People's Republic of China. The secret central committee makes the nominations, is sworn to secrecy—in fact, it is required by this parliament to conduct those discussions in secret—and provides those nominations to the Prime Minister in secret. The Prime Minister can reject that nomination.

So we have a secretive process where the people will not know who the candidate is until that name appears in a joint sitting of the two houses of parliament and then, as senators, we will have a chance to vote on that. That all sounds nice—we have a quasi-democratic process there; almost as democratic as that of the People's Republic of China! I suggest to you, Mr Deputy President, that if you suggested to the people of East Timor that they adopt that same process for the election of their first president they would laugh you out of any international forum.

When it comes to dismissal, at the crucial time when the future head of state needs to make a vital decision about the future of Australia's democracy, resolving conflicts, then the Senate is unilaterally taken out of the decision. All the Prime Minister of the time needs is the support, not of two-thirds of the Parliament, but of 23 per cent of the parliament. On any objective assessment of democratic principles, it cannot be right that the President could be made to go on a decision of 23 per cent of the parliament, when 77 per cent actually support that President.
Sitting suspended from 1.50 p.m. to 2 p.m.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —by leave—I wish to inform the Senate that Senator Vanstone will not be with us today for family reasons. In her place, Senator Ellison will take questions relating to the justice and customs portfolio, the Attorney-General's portfolio and the immigration and multicultural affairs portfolio.

—My question is to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Can the minister confirm that the report jointly sponsored by the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts entitled The IT engine room—SMEs in Australia's IT&T Industry documents the overwhelming view of Australian information technology small to medium enterprises as:

question.para: There will be few winners and many losers as a result of government outsourcing policies.
Doesn't the report also state that the current IT outsourcing program is:
. . . perceived to be inconsistent with the interests of IT&T SMEs?

Given that all of the federal IT outsourcing contracts have been awarded to large multinational corporations, what action has the government taken to ensure these large contracts become accessible to Australian IT companies?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The IT program has been very successful indeed in terms of delivering better value for money for the Commonwealth government. The approach that has been taken has certainly ensured that there has been a very transparent process. There have been obligations imposed to ensure that SMEs are given a fair slice of the action. We can understand the view that some might argue that we should make arrangements to ensure that SMEs get the entire bulk of the work on offer but, at the end of the day, the Commonwealth interest is not what seems to be Senator Lundy's interest—to resurrect the old protection debate—but rather to get better value for money. If SMEs are able to share in the work on offer and are able to be fully considered—and my understanding is that they are—then I think that will be the best outcome for Australia.

answer.para: You are never going to satisfy everyone and clearly a lot more players would be interested. But I am aware of some significant Australian companies who would be regarded as SMEs who are actually doing very well out of it. I think what you will find is that those who do have the capacity to deliver on the ground rather than simply wishing that they did will be the ones that are beneficiaries from the on-sell from the prime contractors.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the minister justify the blind continuation of the federal government's IT outsourcing program given the negative impact expressed by many Australian IT&T businesses? Isn't this just another example of a government program completely contradicting this government's endless rhetoric about fostering the growth of innovative IT businesses?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Madam President, this seems to be all that we get from a taxpayer funded trip of three weeks around Silicon Valley. All you can do is come back and try and resurrect the line that Senator Lundy has been assiduously pursuing to cultivate local support in the ACT region. That has nothing to do with serious government policy. The sooner that Senator Lundy asks for a bit of help on policy, the better off we will all be. You cannot have it both ways. You will find, if you look at what is happening around the world, that governments of all persuasions are going down the path of ensuring that you have efficient operations, that you get best value for taxpayers' dollars and, at the same time, that you make every opportunity available to local suppliers. But we do not, in this day and age, insist on locals getting priority irrespective of merit. I know it is the trade union approach and I know the riding instructions you get, but that is not our approach. We think that the best outcome for taxpayers is actually lower cost burdens—in other words, the capacity to reduce taxes, not increase them. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Mexico led by Senator Jorge Calderon-Salazar. On behalf of senators, I welcome the delegation to the chamber and trust that your visit to this country will be both enjoyable and informative.
—Hear, hear!

—Madam President, my question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate of the failures of the Working Nation program? In contrast, what is the government doing to help the unemployed, in particular those living in rural and regional Australia, to find real jobs? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals? What would be the impact if these were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to receive a real question, particularly when it comes from Senator Eggleston because it does go to the heart of serious policy making in this country: are you interested in getting people back into real work positions, or are you interested in simply pandering to those who might be the very narrow beneficiaries of some of the failed initiatives of the past? Our new Job Network program now involves the provision of four times as many sites as the old CES program. The Work for the Dole pilot program shows that 32 per cent of participants who left the scheme have gone on to unsubsidised employment within three months. That is a pretty fantastic outcome. A Morgan and Banks survey found that nearly 60 per cent of employers would be more likely to employ someone who has been on a Work for the Dole project than someone unemployed without this experience.

answer.para: What is the alternative? The alternative is the failed approach that has been adopted by our predecessors—the old Working Nation program. When poor old Mrs Kernot, who has been absolutely exhausted, we know, and does not have time to leave the electorate these days, was asked last month what she had been doing, she said, `I've certainly been working. I have had lots of meetings with the TWU.' That would be a job strategy endorsed by her successor in title, Mr Ferguson, because that is the main game as far as he is concerned. He is particularly impressed by Working Nation because it benefits the trade unions—`$1.7 million provided to fund training liaison officers.' We know that is a euphemism for making sure that the lads at the Trades Hall get a bit of an extra handout courtesy of the taxpayers.

We have a sensible approach to trying to solve the problems of the unemployed. Those who want to revert to Working Nation ought to accept that it did not deliver the goods. Even Mr Ferguson has said, `It is true that, out of a lot of our training programs, people did not get a job at the end of it.' What a devastating self-indictment. Why would you even contemplate going back on this path? The answer is, of course, that they do not have any policy solutions. That is the tragedy of it. The only glimmer of hope is that Mr McMullan is reported today as saying that Labor might need to start taking some hard policy decisions early in the near term rather than later. This is a revolutionary doctrine! He describes this as a break with tradition.

I do not know who established the tradition; it is basically a failed strategy. The strategy was: `They threw us out in 1996; we'll spend three years doing nothing, keep our heads down, hope no-one notices, and we might slide back in on the unpopularity of the government.' It failed. It did not deliver the goods, but, unfortunately, Mr Beazley has not noticed. Mr Beazley is out there saying, for example, that in March this year he was going to have a vision launch where he promised not simply to put down a set of thoughts but to put those thoughts into material policy. Then he said, `If you like, we will come up with a skeleton of a substantial series of initiatives.' Then, of course, we had a pathways speech on employment that had a rider on the contents page saying, `The options canvassed here have no formal status.' Then he said he would launch a more detailed policy discussion paper in September. Now we know that he cannot ride a horse and chew gum, because that has been put off until after the referendum.

It is simply not good enough. Having a burnt out Rhodes Scholar with all the intellectual policy vigour of Yogi Bear is not going to get you anywhere in the lead-up to the next election. You will have to face up to the fact that Mr McMullan is dead right. The punters do expect a bit of policy alternative. They do not want you to simply go back to the old handout to the trade union mentality that characterised your approach. They want serious programs and mutual obligations. Look at what is going on with your soul brothers over in the UK and you will see the way ahead. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Why didn't the health department require all the parties to negotiations to make a declaration of pecuniary interest and sign undertakings of confidentiality when the process began in February 1998 for negotiation of Medicare rebates for MRI scans?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —This issue has been pursued by the Labor Party for many months in the other chamber. It is related to the magnetic resonance imaging services. It is interesting that the Labor Party, for the 13 years they were in government, did nothing about magnetic resonance imaging, to the extent—
—That's not true!
—Senator Cook is correct. Madam President, I accept that interjection.
—That is an outright lie!

—Order! Senator Cook, you should not be shouting in that fashion across the chamber. There is an appropriate time to take up matters that you might want to debate, and it is not appropriate for you to just sit there and shout.
—Madam President, Senator Cook's interjection was correct and I accept it.
—Tell the truth! When are you lot ever going to be honest?
—Order! Senator Cook, I warn you about the provisions of standing order 203.

—I said he was right, and he is abusing me. If this is not an abusive process, I do not know what is. I have twice said that you were correct, Senator Cook—if you would only listen to the answer. This is classic opposition. They never listen to the answers. They are not interested in the answers. I was wrong; they did do a little about magnetic resonance imaging. In the whole 13 years that they were in power, they allowed in 18 magnetic resonance imaging machines. So Senator Cook was absolutely correct. They allowed 18 magnetic resonance imaging machines into the teaching hospitals.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. This is a serious question about a matter which has been referred to the DPP, as I understand, for prosecution. I think the opposition deserves a serious answer to a serious public policy question, not a rave about what the minister knows about radiology procedures.
—I draw the minister's attention to the question, but I also suggest, Minister, that you perhaps ignore interjections if they occur. I think that was a distraction.

—The question I would ask is this: at how many meetings that the health minister arranged when the Labor Party was in power did they request everybody attending that meeting to give a statutory declaration that they may or may not have a pecuniary interest in whatever discussion was going to occur? That is really what this question is about: did we ask anybody to put in a statutory declaration that they may or may not have had a pecuniary interest in the discussion that was occurring? The answer to the question should be self-evident to even Senator Evans.

answer.para: Since we have been in power we have introduced 91 magnetic resonance imaging machines. They are now available to the general public so that people have the choice of whether they go to a private magnetic resonance imaging institution or to a public hospital. In the development of this process I understand that the department had a total of seven meetings with the College of Radiologists between 10 February and 23 April 1998 to negotiate the proposal for the expansion of funding for MRI services in Australia. That agreement provides for the introduction of medical benefits for MRI and the cooperative management of the diagnostic imaging services table in line with agreed budget guidelines.
So they can go fishing on the other side as much as they like; everything was above board. There has been a case referred, that is true—

talk.start.para: —Was it all above board or not?

—Of course it was above board. We followed the same procedures as the Labor Party followed when they were in power. We do not ask people to produce affidavits at every meeting that they attend saying whether they have got a pecuniary interest one way or the other. It is an absurdity to even suggest it. But what would you expect from the Labor Party? Where are their policies? Is it their policy to have anybody who goes to a meeting sign an affidavit to declare whether they may or may not have a pecuniary interest? The depths they are in at the moment one can understand, because they have got no policies. They are attacking freedom of choice. They are trying to destroy the health system and trying to destroy Medicare, which we are supporting. It is obvious that they have got no answer themselves. We will proceed with the development of that policy and that agreement to make more magnetic resonance imaging machines available to the Australian public.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry that the minister does not think this is a serious issue. Given that the health department knew it had been negotiating with practising radiologists, what arrangements were made to preserve confidentiality for sensitive budget information and to ensure that any pecuniary interests were disclosed?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —One assumes that when one has a meeting about radiology services one talks to radiologists. The Labor Party would not even think of that. That is mind-boggling. That is what occurred. There were meetings with the College of Radiologists and all of the people present had some connection one way or another with the provision of the services. That is how it works. We go and ask the people who are providing services what is the best way for this to be introduced, and this is what occurred.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. How have the government's innovation policies helped develop a vibrant venture capital industry, and how will the government's reforms to business taxation give venture capital a further boost?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Parer for that question about a very important issue for Australia. Our support for venture capital in Australia is turning out to be a real success story. The Australian Venture Capital Journal and PricewaterhouseCoopers recently conducted a survey on this which found that new investments in Australian and New Zealand venture capital projects went up 76 per cent to a record $681 million in 1998-99, with the number of projects also a record. The record number of deals for 1998-99 was driven by a doubling, a 100 per cent increase, in activity in the seed, start-up and early expansion categories.

answer.para: Mr Victor Bivell, the publisher of this journal, said that the government's Innovation Investment Fund and Pooled Development Fund programs must take credit for the increased levels of activity in early stage investments. While I do give credit to the previous government for the Pooled Development Fund Program that we are continuing, we initiated the Innovation Investment Fund, and it is clear that these programs are providing a real stimulus to venture capital. In fact, one-third of the hundred early stage investments in the June quarter alone were due to these programs. The Venture Capital Association executive director, Andrew Green, said that the volume of money coming into the market needs to grow and that the government's Ralph reforms would facilitate this. Of course, our business tax reforms will help in a number of ways. At the moment we have got only about 12 per cent of our funds coming in from international sources compared to 57 per cent coming into the UK, for example. So our decision to exempt eligible investments by foreign pension funds from capital gains tax really is good news for the Australian venture capital industry and for the growth of the Australian economy.

The other major boosts for Australian innovation in the Ralph reforms are the halving of the capital gains tax rate and the cut in the corporate tax rate to 30 per cent. These reforms, taken as a package—it is important to recognise them as a package—will give us a much more internationally competitive business tax regime. As I have said before, this has been most significantly recognised by the Institute of Engineers, which said in response to our Ralph reforms that business tax reforms will result in a rush of foreign money into high technology, more local R&D, more jobs for engineers, a halt to the brain drain and a healthier, more certain climate for domestic investment in start-up companies. I am glad that the opposition agrees with us. I am glad that the opposition recognises the benefits of these reforms. Mr McMullan, my shadow, said in response to the Ralph report release:
Labor supports the government's proposal to provide a CGT exemption to investments in venture capital projects in Australia by overseas pension funds.

I am very glad that not all policy development in the Labor Party has been put off until after the referendum. It is nice to know that the Labor Party have at least one policy in this area and that they will support our package in this most important area. I do hope that they will deliver on that. I do hope that Mr 30 per cent, the Leader of the Opposition, will in fact deal himself back into relevance in Australian public debate and support this package. It is a package that delivers a much better tax system, more investment, more venture capital and ultimately something we should all be concerned about, more jobs.

talk.start.para: —I have a further question to Senator Herron in his capacity representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the investigations undertaken by the Health Insurance Commission into the 31 suspect MRI contracts allegedly entered into by radiologists prior to the May 1998 budget? How many cases has the Health Insurance Commission now referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions? Consistent with the commitment given to me at the estimates committee, will the minister now table the report by the HIC about its investigation?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —As I said previously, the major improvement that we on this side of the House made was increasing the number of magnetic resonance imaging machines that are available to the public. Under the arrangements, Medicare benefits are now available for MRI services. I mentioned previously that there are 92 eligible MRI sites registered with the Health Insurance Commission and of these 84 are accessing Medicare funding. The Health Insurance Commission is proceeding with investigations relating to provider eligibility. I think it would be incorrect to divulge anything in relation to that investigation while it is in progress. The Labor Party may operate that way, but that investigation is proceeding.

answer.para: Of course the magnetic resonance imaging service providers must meet certain requirements in order to be eligible for Medicare benefit payments. These include that providers must be specialists in diagnostic radiology, participating in the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists quality and accreditation program, services must be performed under the professional supervision of an eligible MRI provider, and services must be performed on eligible equipment. The cut-off time for machine eligibility was announced by the government on budget night 1998. Where providers ordered equipment prior to budget night, they are required to provide supporting documentation as part of a statutory declaration. Statutory declarations in relation to equipment on order needed to be provided to the Health Insurance Commission by 11 October this year.

The Health Insurance Commission has been conducting investigations into contracts purported to be signed before the budget as part of its ongoing monitoring role. As I also mentioned previously, one case has been referred to the Director of Public Prosecu tions. Other cases of suspected backdating are being pursued with a view to referral to the Director of Public Prosecutions or the disallowing of benefit claims. Compulsory powers of investigation have been approved under part 2D of the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and additional resources have been allocated to these investigations, which have proved to be more complex than anticipated and have increased in number, leading to a later completion date of November this year.

There have been concerns expressed in relation to the length of time that these investigations are taking, and I take it that that is what Senator Evans is referring to. The minister is confident that the investigations are being properly conducted, and he would emphasise the importance of allowing this process to be completed in a thorough fashion to prevent any need to revisit the investigations in the future. He noted that it has been claimed that 14 new MRI units were purchased by companies associated with members of the executive of the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists and its MRI task force. The Health Insurance Commission has advised him that it does not currently have information that substantiates those claims. I repeat that the Health Insurance Commission has advised the minister that it does not currently have information that substantiates those claims.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for answering the question. What I would like to know, though, is this: is he now saying to the Senate that the report of the HIC will be completed in November? I took that to be what he was saying. If so, can he explain why it was promised in July and now has been delayed till November? Would he also give the Senate the same assurance that I received at the estimates committees that once that report is completed it will be made available to the Senate?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —My interpretation was as Senator Evans said—that the date of the investigations has been extended as additional resources have been allocated to those investigations, because they have proved to be more complex than anticipated and have increased in number. So Senator Evans's interpretation I agree with, from my understanding of that report from the minister. It is understood that it is more important—as I mentioned previously and which he did not listen to—that they should be conducted properly and therefore that meant additional resources. In relation to the provision of the documentation, I will refer that to the minister and get back to Senator Evans with an answer.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. The minister has said previously that the government has accepted the Ralph report figures as its own. Can he then explain why there is a big difference between the government's and the Ralph report's estimates on revenue to be gained from tax avoidance measures? The Ralph report estimates that changes to loss duplication, value shifting and lease assignments, as well as the deferred second stages, will raise $610 million in 2000-01, rising to $900 million by 2004-05, yet the Treasurer's press release of 29 September claims these measures will raise $860 million in 2000-01, rising to $1,660 million by 2004-05. In light of his earlier statement that the government has accepted the Ralph report numbers as its own, can the minister explain this massive discrepancy in figures?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lees for that question. The government has used the costing methodology prepared by the Review of Business Taxation, more commonly known as the Ralph report. The announced integrity measures and the anti-avoidance measures you refer to relate to the tightening of the thirteenth-month rule for advance expenditure, preventing loss duplication and value shifting, addressing the taxation of lease assignments and reforming excess deduction rules for mining operations. The key differences in the government's and Ralph's costings are in respect of the first two measures listed above. The tightening of the prepayment rules has been brought forward to take effect from the date of announcement rather than from 1 July 2000, and the revenue estimates for loss duplication and value shifting measures differ because of the government's decision to delay the implementation of the entity regime to reduce the compliance burden on industry. So one of those measures was brought forward and the other measure was delayed.

answer.para: The integrity and anti-avoidance measures and the deferred package are preventing the alienation of personal services income and deferring deductibility of losses from non-commercial activities. These two measures are assumed to be on the same timetable as in Ralph for the purpose of outlining the fiscal impact of the new business tax system.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask the minister a supplementary question. Is he sure that what is just an adjustment in the timing of some of these measures will make up for a discrepancy that in one year—by the time we get to 2004-05—is over $670 million between Ralph's and the government's estimates? Surely this is a very big risk to take, and the funding hole still exists despite some changes in timing.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The advice I have given the Senate was the advice which I in turn obtained from Treasury and I have no reason to doubt that advice. As I indicated in my remarks, one of the measures was brought forward and another of the measures was delayed. There will always of course be the debate about the revenue estimates but, as I said, we believe they are the best available and of course they are based on the figures which have been prepared in the Ralph report.

—My question is to Senator Newman, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Can the minister explain why she backflipped yesterday on her earlier decision to slash the OSW grant to the National Council for Single Mothers and their Children? Is it because the minister was so embarrassed by her junior minister's revelation that the government had just found an extra $50,000 for the Lone Fathers Association—exactly the same amount that was taken off the single mothers? Now that the minister has admitted her error in defunding this group, when will she reinstate the funding for the remaining nine groups, including Girl Guides Australia, the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Older Women's Network, or must these groups now wait for another slip-up by Larry Anthony before their needs can be met?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Quite clearly, the senator was not paying any attention at all yesterday when I answered in great detail the questions she has just asked. Contrary to some reports in the media—despite my press release which set it out very clearly—my department is funding the National Council of Single Mothers and their Children. The Department of Family and Community Services is the line department that should be funding an organisation like that. Since 1996 the government has been talking about and had a policy on trying to see that NGOs who are relevant to particular line departments are funded wherever possible by that department because they build up a community of interest. It is beneficial to the NGO and it is also beneficial to the public servants who are working in that area to have regular feedback and contact with NGOs in that area. It is very logical. If there is any suggestion that there is something suspicious about the National Council of Single Mothers and their Children being funded by my department, which is dealing with family policy all the time, I would like Labor to try to explain why.

answer.para: There are other organisations that have been funded by line departments. Last year some $350,000 was funded from other portfolios in support of women's organisations. I mentioned some yesterday and I will mention some now. Australian Women in Agriculture got $50,000, the Nursing Mothers Association got $50,000 and the Women's Emergency Services Network, WESNET—who are working so hard in the area of domestic violence—got $80,000. The shame is that Labor never looked at the funding needs of women's NGOs. Labor gave them block grants occasionally. They were always for 12 months. They could drop off the edge of the planet at the end of 12 months and Labor did not care. Labor did nothing to encourage them to become stronger and more effective in their advocacy of the issues for women.

talk.start.para: —Are you still vetting their press releases?
—What have you got against the girl guides?

—Once again I am being given that same shouting down as I try to tell the people what the facts are. As distinct from the line departments that are quite appropriately funding other organisations, in the Office of the Status of Women we set up two funding rounds this year after a long consultation period with women's NGOs. One which has just been announced gives, for the first time ever, three years certainty of funding to women's organisation so that they can set up a national secretariat, employ staff, start working on projects and policy advice to the whole of government and so that they can represent Australian women across the board.

answer.para: If the opposition does not believe that the National Council of Women of Australia—a very large, long respected organisation—and the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women and the YWCA are appropriately funded for a triennium, which has never happened to women's organisations before, they should say it. Which of those organisations does the opposition believe should not be treated like that?

talk.start.para: —We want the rest of them funded as well.

—Senator Mackay is yapping away in the back, Madam President. She is trying to drown out the facts. There is a second round of funding, which I mentioned yesterday, for which a number of organisations have been applying for specific purposes. That will be announced shortly.
—When?
—Very shortly.
—Order! It is not appropriate to sit in the opposition benches and keep shouting out questions.
—Madam President, the only reason they are being announced—
—Stop trying to protect her.
—Senator Conroy, you are out of order.

interjection.para: (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would appreciate a response to our question, which was: when will the announcement be made? Further, is the minister aware of Pru Goward's comments on the 7.30 Report last night that the funding could be given only to a limited number of groups `because we wanted to professionalise the women's movement'? Does the minister endorse this utterly patronising remark? Can she explain precisely how slashing the funding from virtually all national women's organisations will have the effect of so-called professionalising the women's movement?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I wish I had more than one minute to answer that question. As I was trying to say when the time was called against me, the only reason that there is a second round of funding—which will be announced very shortly—is that the women's organisations themselves asked for more time. You would understand that often NGOs have difficulty in meeting some deadlines and they can ask for an extended time, and we agreed to that. They will be announced very shortly. We heard an awful lot from the ALP yesterday about girl guides. Girl guides received funding of $50,000 last year. They were not funded at all by the previous government.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order which goes to relevance. The question was: does the minister agree with the comments of Pru Goward on the 7.30 Report last night? I would appreciate it if she got to that quickly.

—I addressed that issue at the very beginning of my answer about national secretariats being effective. OSW has worked with these organisations to help them prepare to be as effective as they have. The Women's Action Alliance, who were here in Canberra yesterday, received funding of $25,000 in 1997-98 and in 1998-99. They received a total of just over $8,000 for the 13 years of the last government. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Alston, representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Does the government support pregnancy testing for women prior to employment as part of its response to a survey by the International Labour Organisation in respect of maternity protection at work? Who authorised the response by the government to the survey, and what are the reasons for responding to the survey in this way?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Can I make it clear that the government did not oppose a prohibition on pre-employment pregnancy testing at the ILO—
—They did so.
—Oh, boy! I've got something to wave too.
—Senator Alston, ignore the interjections.
—I will, Madam President.

answer.para: Senator Hill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, it just shows you. I gather the source of the report was someone who attended the ILO conference in Geneva at the expense of the ACTU, so maybe that is where the confusion arises, Senator Collins. Get your information from outside the ACTU. You might have a better idea.

answer.para: An earlier departmental response to the ILO questionnaire clearly opposed pregnancy testing, which is discriminatory. However, the response did reflect a minor legal concern that there may be instances where general medical test results on prospective employees may be misleading without the knowledge that the person was pregnant. Pregnancy tests conducted and used in the process of interpreting such general tests would not be discriminatory. The government is unequivocally of the view, and made it clear during the first discussion of this matter at the ILO conference in Geneva in June this year, that it supported a prohibition on pregnancy testing for prospective employees.
