The government is strongly supportive of the rights of women in employment to have children and raise families free from fear of discrimination. Australia has put in place strong legal protections to protect women against discrimination on the basis of pregnancy. Discrimination on the basis of pregnancy or potential pregnancy in applying for employment is prohibited in Australian legislation at the federal level, via the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. It is also prohibited under state based legislation. To ensure these protections are adequate, the government commissioned the pregnancy discrimination inquiry, which was the first of its kind in Australia. This highlights the importance the government places on ensuring the fair treatment of women in the workplace.
Senator Harradine asked me what the reasons were for responding to the survey in a particular way, and I can tell him that the caveat attached to the answer to the question was:

. . . that a provision of this nature should prohibit discrimination on the basis of the manner in which the test is required or how the result of the test is used, rather than hinge on the mere fact of the test being conducted. Many workplaces require potential employees to have a medical examination prior to being permanently appointed. That medical examination may include a pregnancy test to enable accurate interpretation of the test results.

talk.start.para: —What fool framed this response?
—You are not listening.
—It is right here.
—Well get your information from outside. I am telling you what is in the answer, so if you have got the answer we are in heated agreement.
—It is here and it is the coalition's response.
—It might be there. Very good for you. I am delighted you have got a copy of it. It continues:

answer.para: Where the test is taken with the employee's informed consent and done for bona fide purposes, it would be unnecessary to penalise the employer, as no harm has been done to the employee in these circumstances.

talk.start.para: —Oh, yeah, right!

—Suddenly the penny has dropped, has it? Australia did not press the caveat from the questionnaire and supported a prohibition on pregnancy testing at the first discussion on the topic at the ILO conference in Geneva in June this year. All I can suggest is that those who have beaten this up ought to get their information from the source.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The response has confused me. I understood the minister to say, in short, that the government is not opposing pregnancy testing asked for by the employer, provided the prospective employee agrees. Yet the pressure that is on women in this day and age—with high unemployment—to get a job is such that they are virtually forced to agree in order to get the job. I think we should have that clarified, Minister, so that we can all see what the response of the government was and what is now the view and the true position of the government. Could we have the documentation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Let me be quite clear. The caveat—in other words, the additional comment attached to the answer to the survey questionnaire—did make the point that I elaborated. But at the end of the day Australia did not press that caveat and supported a prohibition on pregnancy testing at the first discussion on the topic at the ILO conference, so the government did not oppose a prohibition on pre-employment pregnancy testing at the ILO. Prior to any of those decisions being taken, there were surveys circulated and our answer spelled out the circumstances that I described earlier. In other words, it may well be argued that in order to properly interpret a general health test, you need to know whether someone is pregnant. But when it came to the specific issue of whether we would support a prohibition, we did not oppose that prohibition.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Minister, isn't it a fact that all of the community women's organisations defunded by the Howard government have spoken out against the GST over the past 12 months? Isn't the defunding of these community groups this government's payback for community opposition to its tax package? Is the minister aware of the statement by the WEL spokesperson, on the 7.30 Report last night, who said they had been `critical, highly critical, of this government's policies in a range of areas that directly impact on the quality of women's lives. The government now wants us to be quiet, and that's what they're attempting to do by defunding us'? Doesn't this make a mockery of the Prime Minister's social coalition, especially when the government will go to any length to muzzle all disagreement to give the illusion of support for the government's policies?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I draw the Senate's attention to the two organisations that got either little or no funding from Labor while they were in government—the guides and the Women's Action Alliance would not have too much to say thank you for to the previous government, yet they have had assistance from this government. If we are going to talk about WEL, let us be honest—we are not talking about all women's organisations; we are talking about the organisation that fronts for the ALP, and I say that very advisedly.
—They've got a bit to say about you, too.
—I have only four minutes and I wanted to make sure I put it all down, Senator. In 1972 I was a founding member of WEL. In 1975 I left WEL—
—When it became unWEL?

—Yes, they became very unwell. I was first of all a member in Sydney. But later, in 1975, in Launceston they called an emergency meeting to decide whether they were going to join the fight to get Gough Whitlam back into government—they were maintaining the rage. The alternative was: would they maintain their feminist principles and work—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Labor senators will cease shouting. You are absolutely disorderly. There is an appropriate time to pursue and debate the matter later if you wish.

—Madam President, they do not like to hear it. This is history. People who go back as far as I do know it. WEL decided to walk away from their feminist principle of getting women into parliament, and their history shows they have not done anything about that or about maintaining women's issues on the national agenda. They have been very slow.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The behaviour of senators is absolutely out of order. It is interfering with question time, making it impossible for other people to listen. It is totally disorderly.
—I go back a long way in working for women and women's refuges in very practical ways.
—You are a disgrace as a minister.
—Senator Mackay, I draw your attention to standing order No. 203—persistent and wilful interjections are disorderly and may be reported to the Senate.

—I was a founding member of two women's refuges in the 1970s, when it was not quite as crash hot an issue to be associated with them as it is these days. It was regarded as something only lesbians would have any interest in, Senator Faulkner—you may be interested. I was a strong public advocate for the need for women's refuges.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I don't know what that comment was about—
—That's not a point of order, Senator.

—Madam President, with respect, I think this minister is absolutely out of control. I was sitting here trying to listen to an extraordinarily garbled answer. I do not know what she is talking about or why she is directing comments like that across the chair to me. You know that is out of order. I do not know what she is responding to or why she is saying such things. It is obviously very insulting to many people in the community. You really ought to draw this minister's attention to the proper forms of the House and to the question that has been asked of her. She ought to be directed to respond sensibly and seriously to a question that has been asked of her. She should do so through you and she should be drawn to order by you if she subverts the standing orders of this place in the way she has just been doing.
—There is no point of order.

—I simply made the point that it is okay to be an advocate when everybody else is endorsing it, but when people are very suspicious of some new change in the community, like women's refuges in 1974 and 1975, then it takes a bit of guts to get out and advocate for women. I would like to conclude my answer by saying that the first funding round, which has been completed and announced, was totally at arm's length from me. It was done by a selection panel, which made recommendations to me and I accepted those recommendations. Women's organisations have not in fact been defunded. There are women's organisations still waiting to hear whether or not they have been funded.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Along with the muzzling of groups by withdrawing all their funding, hasn't the Howard government also been gagging any critical feedback from women by cutting 30 community groups from the upcoming women's round table consultations? Can the minister confirm Pru Goward's statement last night that this was aimed at creating `a more intimate format'? How does this narrowing of consultation fit with the minister's 1996 statement that she wanted to `listen to the views of small organisations out of the Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra axis'? Is there anything this government will not do, any length of hypocrisy it will not go to, to squeeze out all independent community comment on the disastrous effects of its policies on women?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Once again, one minute will not do the job. The women's roundtable was established for a two-day session by me so that women's organisations could get a better chance of having an ex change of views with government and be more valuable to them. That was at their request because the programs we inherited from Carmen Lawrence did not give women's organisations an opportunity to have their own agendas raised with the government. So that is the first thing. The second thing is that the women's organisations have come to the government again and said that they would like more time to raise issues because the number of organisations that would be there meant that there was very constrained time for discussion. We looked to see what we could do to make sure that it was a more meaningful and valuable experience for women's NGOs; therefore, we have reduced the number of women from about 50 to about 40. I think the ALP is running up a blind alley on that, too. In addition, I have a group of colleagues who work with me in each state and territory to consult with women in roundtable discussions. We have a multitude of mechanisms for consulting with women. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister please inform the Senate of the very important ways in which the Howard government has assisted regional communities since 1996. How will these initiatives assist regional Australia in dealing with change?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —This question demonstrates Senator Ferris's continuing interest in regional Australia—an interest which, regrettably, is not shared by the opposition spokesman in this chamber on regional matters. Senator Ferris was in the South Australian pastoral districts just yesterday consulting with people in the bush, listening to their problems and advising them of the initiatives of the government. Change is upon us in the late industrial age as we move into the early information technology age. That change is inevitable. Many in rural and regional Australia have embraced that change and have done very well. The government is helping with that change. Perhaps the best we can do for rural and regional Austral ia is to get rid of that tyranny of distance that has held regional Australia back for so long. We have done that with Senator Alston's initiative in the telecommunications area. With telecommunications you can kill that distance that has held Australia back.

answer.para: The GST has been a tremendous thing for rural and regional Australia. It is a policy that the National Farmers Federation demanded for many years.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise and the extent to which senators are breaching the standing orders is unacceptable. I ask them to take note of the standing orders and behave accordingly.

—The National Farmers Federation embraced the GST because it meant $4.5 billion annually off our costs of exports. It meant that every farmer in Australia would save about $7,500 in the removal of costs. No matter what the Labor Party ever says, promises or does in regional Australia, never will it hide the fact that it opposed the tax reform package. It opposed the cuts in costs to people in rural and regional Australia. Part of that initiative by the Howard government has been the reduction in transport costs. The new Labor shadow spokesman on regional matters, Mr Martin Ferguson, lives 10 kilometres from the centre of Melbourne. He would not understand the importance of transport and transport costs to people who live in regional and rural Australia. Mr Ferguson cannot be expected to understand that. The reduction in fuel costs, some 23c a litre on transport vehicles, means real and big savings for those of us who live in the bush.

answer.para: Perhaps the best thing we have done to help regional Australians cope with the change is to get the big picture right. Our management has reduced interest rates away from Mr Beazley's black hole of the $10 billion deficit. We have reduced interest rates very substantially and given businesses in rural and regional Australia the opportunity to get ahead. Ten years ago under Mr Beazley local governments were paying almost 15 per cent for their loans. They are now paying six to seven per cent on indicative rates—a saving of around eight per cent. If you cast that across the average debt of local government, that is a saving each year of some $800,000 to each council.

All the Labor Party and Mr Ferguson can do—as he did in the parliament yesterday—is to criticise our initiatives in cutting down the cost of transport to rural and regional Australia. He does not have a policy. Mrs Kernot said she had been working on it for ages and that she had handed a lot over to Mr Ferguson. I call upon Mr Ferguson to release some of that policy. Do what Mr McMullan said he had asked him to do yesterday: release some policies. Let us see what you have for rural and regional Australia. Let us see what you have that might match what the government has done for the people in that area. Do what Mr McMullan said: get your policies out so we can see what you have got. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could Senator Macdonald explain the way in which the Rural Plan works for regional Australia. This was one of the very important issues raised at the meeting yesterday.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris. Senator Ferris was in the pastoral districts to explain to the pastoralists—to the country people there—about this initiative of the government, Rural Plan, whereby the government will provide a community with some money to work out a strategy. Senator Ferris is asking the question because she is trying to help the Labor Party, who occasionally would get out into the bush. We hope Mr Ferguson, unlike Mrs Kernot, might get out there and tell them about Rural Plan, which is a tremendous initiative. It builds on all our other rural initiatives—the $1½ billion that Senator Hill has put into the rural environment and the $70 million rural transaction centre initiative, the first of which the Prime Minister will be opening at the end of this month. Those are the sorts of initiatives which you should know about. Regrettably, no-one on the Labor side seems to know about it. They do not promote it, but they are great initiatives for the bush. Senator Ferris, I do thank you for alerting the people in your area to Rural Plan and the good things that it can do for the South Australian pastoral community.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Does the minister recall telling the Senate yesterday that `expenditure on research and development under this government is actually higher than it was ever under any full year under the Labor government'? Isn't it the case that, according to the minister's own science and technology budget statement, while this government's spending on R&D for 1999-2000 is $638.6 million, spending by the previous Labor government on R&D was higher in three previous full years—that is, $713.1 million in 1992-93, $852.1 million in 1993-94, and $888.6 million in 1994-95?

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Conroy, I have not heard the last part of your question because of senators shouting across the chamber.
—When will the minister correct this blatant mislead, which was obviously made in a desperate attempt to defend this government's appalling record on R&D?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —It does appear that Senator Conroy did not actually think about the question he asked yesterday before he asked it when he was handed it. His question yesterday clearly was about the level of business expenditure on R&D in Australia; it was not about the level of government support for R&D. I answered that question. If he had wanted me to answer another question he should have asked it. I answered that question. I said in my answer, quite correctly:

answer.para: Expenditure on R&D under this government is actually higher than it ever was in any full year under the Labor government.

My claim is absolutely correct. I am prepared to table this very good table of expenditure on R&D by business enterprises from 1968-69 to 1997-98, which clearly establishes the accuracy of the statement I made yesterday.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister also recall saying to the Senate in relation to business expenditure on R&D that `R&D is at what are otherwise record levels'? Is it not the case that the most recent ABS statistics on business expenditure on R&D showed that while BERD was at $4,043.8 million in 1997-98, this was down on the levels achieved in the two previous years, namely 1995-96, of $4,343 million; and 1996-97, of $4,200 million? Will the minister now correct this mislead, or is he determined not to let the facts stand in the way of this desperate story?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —Once again, the ALP too readily glosses over exactly what ministers like me actually say. He is claiming that I was wrong to say that R&D is at what are otherwise record levels. I chose my words carefully. I said `otherwise' record levels. What Mr McMullan failed to point out in his press release was that I referred to the peak years immediately preceding it. This table again makes my point. The last two years under us have been the second and third best years ever for business R&D in Australia. Yes, we did come off a record high in 1995-96 when we were both in government but, as I say, the figures were artificially inflated by that being the peak of the rorting of the R&D syndication mechanism, which you had already announced you were going to do something about. So again, my statements were absolutely correct.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Service (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by Senators Mackay and Crossin today, relating to funding of women's organisations and the answer given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston) to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine relating to pre-employment pregnancy test requirements.

Finally today the cat was let out of the bag in relation to why women's organisations that were defunded were defunded. This minister said it herself. She alleges that WEL is a front for the Labor Party. She said it. The cat is out of the bag. I wonder how many women there are on the other side of the chamber who are members of WEL.

talk.start.para: —Who would want to be?

—It gets worse and worse. I wonder how many women on the other side of the chamber are members of WEL. I wonder how many women senators in the coalition are utterly mortified and embarrassed by the performance of this minister in relation to this incident regarding the funding of women's organisations. There are a number of women on the other side of the chamber who have a good attitude in relation to issues that affect women. I have had conversations with them. When this minister got up yesterday and talked about the sisterhood—I am assuming that she meant women on this side—I looked at the faces of the women on the other side of the chamber and they were embarrassed. They were absolutely mortified.

speech.para: Similarly, when Senator Newman talked about `those feminists on the other side of the chamber' there were a number of women on the other side of the chamber who were also really embarrassed. I know for a fact that there are a number of women in the coalition who are embarrassed about the performance of this minister and the government in relation to women. Senator Coonan took the extraordinary action—correctly so—of cautioning the Prime Minister prior to the last election, saying: `If you do this, if you go down this track in relation to women, you will lose votes.' Senator Coonan was absolutely correct because the gender gap for the first time in Australian history went Labor's way in relation to women. Why is that? It is because of the policies of this government.

To add insult to injury, we had outrageous statements by Ms Pru Goward last night on the 7.30 Report. She said that the basic thrust in relation to the defunding of women's organisations was to professionalise the women's movement. That is utterly patronising. I wonder how the Girl Guides feel about that. I wonder how the Catholic Women's League feel about that. I wonder how the Older Women's Network feel about that. I wonder how they feel about being described as unprofessional, about the fact that they have been defunded because Ms Pru Goward and the minister decided that they wanted to professionalise the women's movement. They were absolutely outrageous comments which the minister should be completely embarrassed about. I am pleased Senator Patterson finds it so amusing because it is not funny to the women out there in the Catholic Women's League, in the Older Women's Network and in the Girl Guides that have not been funded because they are not regarded by this government as professional enough to be consulted in relation to women's policy. Those statements were outrageous.

Yesterday we had a situation where the minister was embarrassed because there were a number of stories in the media in relation to the issue of defunding women's groups. This is the very same minister who was asked last sitting week by me and by a number of other senators as to whether this was likely, whether it was going to be the case. In fact, she was asked the day before the announcement was made about the defunding of women's organisations. What was her normal disdainful and patronising response to those questions? `I'm not going to deign that with an answer.' That is what she said. The very next day, she put out a press release confirming what we were alleging about the defunding of women's groups. She had no intention of answering that question.

Then we had some interest from the media. All of a sudden, $50,000 worth of discretionary funding was found out of her own department. That is fine; good. What we want is to get all of those women's organisations refunded, even the ones that this government regards as Labor Party fronts, like WEL. It was interesting today to hear the meandering through Senator Newman's past as to her experience with WEL in relation to their decision whether or not they would support the Whitlam government at that point. That was the reason why WEL did not receive the funding. I wonder what the Catholic Women's League have done to Senator Newman. I wonder what the Older Women's Network have done to Senator Newman. I wonder what the Girl Guides have done to Senator Newman. This minister is an absolute disgrace. She cannot even front when the Office of the Status of Women are at estimates. She ought to be deprived of this portfolio. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One of the things that Labor is best at is myths and misrepresentation. From what Senator Mackay has just said, you would think that there is no money left for a second round of funding. What has happened is that $300,000 has been given out in the first round to three organisations and, as Senator Newman said in answer to a question, on a triennium basis for the first time women's organisations have been funded for three years in order for them to make plans and organise themselves ahead, and there is $200,000 still to be allocated to organisations in the second round.

speech.para: I have to admit a vested interest as a member of the Girl Guides Association of Australia. Only last Saturday, I completed a term on the council of the Victorian Girl Guides Association. Whenever I have been approached by anybody in guiding as to whether they should have government funding I have said, `No, I don't think we should ever apply for government funding.' One of the reasons I have always said that is that from my time in guiding, from the age of 10, we were always trained and brought up to work for what we had. That is why guiding and scouting has `Cents for service', what was called in the olden days `Willing shilling', in order to be able to fund ourselves. So my preference is not for our association to have funding. There are others in my organisation who may disagree with that.

In general, we have managed, and we managed under Labor with no funding whatsoever out of OSW for general grant funding which the Guides got last year. Having expressed my personal preference, I want to say that it is misleading for Labor to say that we are going to defund organisations, when $200,000 remain. It is also misleading to say that Senator Newman magically found some $50,000 for the National Council for Single Mothers, when in fact she has diligently asked every minister to look at ways and means in which their portfolios can fund women's organisations out of mainstream budget lines.

We have seen that happen out of the Office of Disability—$50,000 for sport for women with disabilities. We have seen funding for rural women through the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. As Senator Newman said, organisations then have direct contact with the principal departments, so they are meeting with officers and bureaucrats who are working on policy and developing the government's responses, and have first-hand access, so that rural women feed into the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and women with disabilities have direct contact with the Office of Disability. So Senator Newman actually practised what she was preaching by funding the National Council for Single Mothers out of the Department of Family and Community Services. That is the approach she has been taking.

talk.start.para: —She finally gave money to the custodial parents rather than to the non-custodial parents.

—You will have your time soon, Senator Crossin. Regarding the women's roundtable, people were shouting on the other side about reducing the number, but when Carmen Lawrence was minister for women's affairs she would float into the women's roundtable, give her introductory speech, and then float out again. They never saw Carmen Lawrence. She would float in and float out.
—She could not remember to come back.

—She forgot to come back; that is right, Senator Ferris. They said that when Senator Newman came she stayed for the whole roundtable and they were very impressed. What Senator Newman has also done is appoint one member or senator for each state to go around and talk to women, to be a conduit back to her. The Labor Party did not have this. Senator Ferris has had 10 roundtables in her state. We meet with Senator Newman in her office on a regular basis. She questions us about what women are saying in our states. We meet on a regular basis in her office. Do not tell us she is not getting information. She is using us to tell her what women are saying in those roundtables. To have the Labor Party saying that there has been a decrease in consultation is outrageous. (Time expired)

—I should at the outset declare an interest, still being an officer of the largest women's organisation in Australia—the SDA. I wish to concentrate on answers by Senator Newman and Senator Alston concerning pregnancy testing in the workplace and defunding of various women's groups and organisations around Australia. Those questions and answers go to the bona fides of the government in this area of women's interests, women's advancement and the need for professionalism, as stated by the minister. The respective answers highlight the ineptitude of the government. When the current government came to power, it made much ado about a new approach, a new focus, about being more inclusive, more consultative. All of those individuals on the outer, or previously excluded, were to be consulted and made part of the new team. The issues covered in the question by Senator Harradine and other senators to Senator Newman put the lie to that proposition.

speech.para: The issues covered by the questions go to the heart and soul of equal opportunity in Australia. In 20 years in public life I can recall being involved in many campaigns on behalf of female workers and women generally. There were campaigns for equal pay in the seventies, maternity leave by award coverage, superannuation and financial security for low paid private sector workers, sexual harassment-free workplaces and, finally, the right to choose to return to work after the birth of a child and the right to child care and equity based assistance from government. There was nothing remarkable—just incremental change, gradual improvement, affecting half of the population, giving them the right and the ability to choose to work for reward. Critical to the decision has been consideration of policy matters relating to child care, maternity leave and employment access.

For almost the last 15 or 20 years it has been settled law in Australia that discrimination against individuals on a range of grounds is illegal. Nearly every award contains a provision to outlaw discrimination on grounds of age, gender, sexuality, ethnic origin and religious belief. Yet the government, Minister Alston and Minister Newman, on behalf of the Office of the Status of Women, say nothing. They offer no defence and make no explanation as to why the Australian government try to hurt pregnant women in international forums.

Nearly all women in Australia at some time in their life want to have a family. Most women and families need income support in the years of childbirth and child-rearing. Many women and families need, or want, the mother to return to paid employment. Yet here we have Minister Alston apparently acquiescing in the decision of Minister Reith in international forums saying that the position of the Australian government is that female workers should undergo pregnancy testing as a pre-employment condition. Minister Alston apparently believes that half the population of Australia, in their child-bearing years, should be pregnancy tested to obtain the right to work.

If the government have made a simple mistake, the sensible thing to do would be to fess up, to outline the facts and to move on to issues of concern. But they have not done that. They have tried to cover up their delegation to the ILO conference and their voting behaviour and pattern. We hear no explanation; we hear no apology. The conclusion is blindingly obvious. The government—these ministers—cannot bring themselves to tell the entire story, to tell the truth. They pay lip-service to ideas and principles of equal opportunity for female workers. The real position, as disclosed on the other side of the world, is to line up with nine or 10 minor countries out of a total of 180 and give the quiet nod to discrimination practices that have been illegal in Australia for 15 or 20 years. This is a shameful and backward position. Now is the time for the respective ministers to unequivocally clear the record and put the position straight.

Minister Alston, Minister Newman and Minister Reith, in the other place, should state the position of the Australian government as one of support for pregnant workers, opposed to any form of discrimination against female workers, and particularly opposed to pre-employment pregnancy checks for female workers. We have not had that clear statement from Minister Alston today. He tried to get around it by saying that the Australian delegation changed its position—had a number of positions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What a diatribe! What a diatribe from the party of myths and legends—not a single policy anywhere from the party of myths and legends! We heard some myths earlier in question time today and some incredible screaming from Senator Mackay as she tried to perpetuate the myth that in some way the coalition had defunded women's organisations. What a myth.
—You have.

—Senator Crossin, you know better. We have maintained a minimum of $500,000 annually most years, including this one. In fact, this year the level of funding has been higher than that. Prior to the announcement of the funding for the major organisations, $125,000 had already been provided from OSW for operational activities by women's organisations for the first quarter of this financial year, and very soon a further round of project grants of up $25,000 each for women's organisations to undertake projects to advance the status of women and to strengthen their organisations will be made. This will bring the total funding for women's organisations' activities this year to well over $500,000.

speech.para: Our strategy to assist organisations which provide services to women includes not only the OSW funding but also a recognition that many of the issues of concern to women cut across portfolios held by other ministers. We encourage women's organisations to work with those ministers' offices. Last year, in working with other ministers' offices in this way, we actually awarded an extra $350,000 to organisations from other Commonwealth areas. I would have thought that was a record of which we could be very proud.

In her contribution this afternoon, Senator Patterson referred to a number of female senators from around Australia who represent the minister in various ways in their home state. I am very proud to say that I am one of those senators. I frequently have had the opportunity to meet with women from a wide range of areas of interest—women in the home, women in the work force, multicultural women, indigenous women and women who have particular needs for children in care and young people in care.

talk.start.para: —I bet they gave you a hard time.

—I have had 10 of these roundtables around the state and I will tell you what they gave me a hard time about, as Senator Faulkner has just commented. It was the fact that never before had they had the opportunity to be listened to by a federal senator.
—I bet they never want to do it again.
—Never before had they been invited to meet with a female federal senator, because nobody in my state had previously shown any interest at all.
—First and last time.

—Senator Faulkner, I have met several times with many of the women and they cannot wait to come back and meet again, because on each occasion the contributions that they have made in those meetings with me have been taken up with the relevant ministers, and they have been followed through to the extent that I have had many letters thanking me for the issues that have been resolved in this way.

speech.para: In particular, I would like to mention the indigenous women's roundtables. I have had one in Port Adelaide and one in Port Augusta. I have spoken about them before in this place. They have been very successful. They have raised issues with me about indigenous family violence. Those issues have been taken up with Minister Herron and I am very glad to say that they have now been taken up as policy. Senator Crossin, as you well know, I have taken up those issues from your Northern Territory during the parliamentary break.

talk.start.para: —Who represents the Northern Territory in your little meetings with Senator Herron?
—Those comments that were made there were also passed on to Senator Herron and were incorporated in policy positions.

speech.para: I come from an age—as you do, Madam Deputy President—when it was very difficult to fight for women's issues. On many occasions we had difficulty in the work force because there were not many women. When I started work, I was one girl with 80 men. I was an 18-year-old in an organisation where women were not normally employed. It was not easy. We have not forgotten those fights and we never will. On this side of the chamber we represent women as strongly and effectively as they ever have been represented. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am relieved that in today's question time session taking note of answers we have allowed scope to deal with Senator Harradine's question in relation to the pregnancy issue. Following Senator Ferris's comments, the facts of the matter still have not come out. Like Senator Harradine, I was fairly dissatisfied with the response from Senator Alston and I was going to be asking Senator Newman pretty much the same question. Given Senator Newman's response to other questions in question time today, I doubt that I would have had a satisfactory answer from her. Even though we have taken note of this issue today, neither Senator Patterson nor Senator Ferris has dealt with this issue. Perhaps it is embarrassment. Perhaps the next government speaker might throw some more light onto it. I see Senator Ferris leaving the chamber. The facts of the matter are these. How on earth did that survey question ever get filed on behalf of the Australian government? As Senator Alston has already admitted, the government then retreated from that situation, but how on earth did it every happen in the first place? Senator Alston is right. The answer we gave to that survey is inconsistent with Australian law. But that still does not answer the question: how on earth did it ever happen in the first place?

speech.para: Let me go to the precise question. I do not need a lesson from Senator Alston on ILO practice, procedure or correct government documentation to the ILO. I have the relevant documentation here. The question that was asked and completed by the Australian government was:
When a woman is applying for employment, should employers be prohibited from requiring a test for pregnancy or a certificate of such a test, . . .

Should an employer be prohibited? The answer quite clearly was no—full stop. Then we go on to a comment—not a caveat. This is not a caveat on the answer of no. This is simply a comment. The comment can basically be described as, `We can justify allowing this to happen on the basis that it is not the act itself but only if discrimination occurs that is the problem.' But as Senator Harradine already pointed out in question time today, if a woman wants a job she is going to comply. If a woman wants the job and this is a condition established by the employer, then the woman is going to comply.

Let me highlight another inadequacy with the government's response. The government talks about the problem of medical tests. If a general medical test is required for employment, then pregnancy may impact on that test. As I said to a journalist during this debate, the answer to that situation is quite simple. It is very simple. If you need to know if a woman is pregnant to justify some other test, then it can be a confidential matter between the doctor and the woman. It does not have to be a test that the employer is aware of. Any adequate practitioner can keep such information confidential to themselves. It does not have to go to the employer.

Again, the Australian government was sorely embarrassed in this situation. It was embarrassed to join only these countries: Argentina, Bahrain, Guyana, Indonesia, Jamaica, Papua New Guinea and Zimbabwe. I hope women on the other side are embarrassed by this performance. Our representatives at the ILO did eventually back away from this position, thank God. But how on earth did we get into this embarrassing position in the first place? Was there no woman present on the delegation? Maybe that is one highlight of why it might have occurred. Certainly, I know it would not have occurred from representation by our government in the past. I know many adequate women officers within the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business who would never have allowed this situation to arise in relation to a survey.

The only government response that I have seen so far is from Tony Abbott, Minister for Employment Services, saying the contrary to today's media reports. The media reports were accurate. We have not had from the government to date an accurate response as to how on earth it put itself in this position in an international forum and embarrassed all Australian women—because that is what it did. Its treatment of the funding of women's organisations is just further embarrassment. It is not professionalising the women's movement, as Pru Goward said last night. It is actually highlighting what it is really about: representing only the right woman. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Firstly, may I do what Senator Bishop did and declare my interest in these women's issues. It is not a personal interest, unlike Senator Bishop. I am not sure which organisations Senator Bishop mentioned that he is a member of, but I am adviser to Melbourne's Asian Women's Association, which is an association that by declaration does not receive government funding. It is, like many Asian associations, a community association which depends on its own effort.

speech.para: I am somewhat at a disadvantage in that I was under the impression that when we take notice of answers, we take notice of one particular answer. But when Senator Bishop suddenly got up and started carrying on about how women's rights have developed—quite properly—and how women had gained rights in this country, I must admit that I spent something like four minutes trying to pick up how it would differ from the alleged defunding of women's organisations.

talk.start.para: —It's a good speech. You should read it in Hansard .
—Unfortunately, Senator Faulkner, Hansard does not work that fast. However, I assume that there are actually two motions to take notice of.

—Senator Tchen, there is only one motion to take notice of, and it is to take notice of answers given by Senator Newman in response to a number of opposition questions, and also the answer given by Senator Alston to Senator Harradine's question. That is the motion.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I am in debt to you for your direction. In that case, can I first refer to Senator Newman's answers. It occurs to me that, obviously, senators on the other side did not listen to the answers given by the minister. Much has been made of certain organisations being supposedly defunded, but there are two things that the minister said which are fundamental to the whole issue. Firstly, she said that it is this government's policy that funding should be carried out by line departments. In other words, departments like the Office of the Status of Women should assist women's groups to start activities and encourage them to carry out activities which will improve the position of women in society, as an initial step, and, once the groups have established their direction of interest, funding should be gained from departments, and other sources, which are more directly involved in those areas. For example, as the minister said, last year $350,000 additional funding was obtained by women's organisations from other sources. In fact, it is one of the areas in which the Office of the Status of Women actually assists organisations to obtain funding.

speech.para: The second thing that the minister said which seemed to escape the attention of the senators on the other side is that there is a second round of funding to come, consisting of something like $250,000, which is half of the funding that the Office of the Status of Women usually allocates. So it is totally premature for the senators on the other side to get upset about a report on organisations which are supposedly missing out. I will make two points about Senator Bishop's and Senator Collins's comments. Their tirades seem to make two fundamentally flawed assumptions. The question which is being asked should be regarded on a medical ground because every employer has the responsibility to know the wellbeing of their employees. If you assume that automatically all employers are antiwomen, yes, you have a concern. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.
—I seek leave to make a comment for 30 seconds on that matter.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. All I wanted to say has already been said—and said much better than I would have said it—by Senators Collins and Bishop. All I want to do now is to suggest to the government that they have a very good look at this. I know it is difficult for a minister representing another minister—in this case Senator Alston, representing Mr Reith—to be fully over the brief, but I do believe that what is in the brief is a diversion and does not respond to the very substantial questions that I raised. I would hope the government might see its way to make perfectly clear to all and sundry what its true position is on this particular matter and why what took place did in fact take place.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex,
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

talk.start.para: Senator Harradine(from 17 citizens)

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

talk.start.para: —I present the 17th report of 1999 of the Selection of Bills Committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be adopted.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to have the report incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—
1. The Committee met on 12 October 1999.
2. The committee resolved to recommend-
(a) That the following bills be referred to committees:

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AMENDMENT (AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCE SERVICE AND TRAINING) BILL 1999 (No. 2)

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Jacinta Collins) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to ensure that leave for participation in service and training as a member of the Australian Defence Force Reserves is one of the matters which may be taken into account by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for conciliation and arbitration.
Motion (by Senator Jacinta Collins) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memorandum and I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Defence Force Service and Training) Bill 1999 gives back to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission the power to include leave for Reservists to participate in the activities necessary to be a member of the Australian Defence Force Reserves.

The fact that it is necessary for the Labor Party to move such a provision should be a matter of some embarrassment for this Government and the Minister for Workplace Relations, if embarrassment is ever possible, because it is required as the result of the Howard Government's 1996 amendments to the Workplace Relations Act.

That legislation excluded Defence Force Leave from the 20 allowable Award matters that the Industrial Commission were able to deal with. It stands as one of the most foolhardy examples of the Government's zealous pursuit of their industrial relations agenda. There is some stiff competition, however. Senators may recall that in the same fell swoop the Government took away the Commission's power to make Awards on such extreme things as: occupational health and safety matters; meal break facilities; amenities for people in lunch rooms; the fact that there should be first aid kits provided in workplaces; or sexual harassment matters.

It is an indication of this government's obsession about industrial relations that it has been willing to sacrifice good defence policy on the altar of its flat earth industrial relations obsessions. It has been a pursuit of its divisive and ideologically driven industrial relations agenda at whatever cost. And the agenda continues, with the Government's 2nd wave of industrial intervention, currently before a Senate committee inquiry.

If there is one thing worse than bad policy, which this clearly is, it is refusing to accept that a mistake has been made, and refusing to rectify that mistake. And this Government can be under no illusions that they made a boo-boo. Since the 1996 amendments, they have received and continually ignored advice that a mistake was made, and it needs to be rectified.

The Defence Reserve Support Committee is an important structure within the defence establishment that assists in resolving difficulties between Reservists and their private employers. It is chaired by Sir James Killen, who is well known to many here. The minutes of its meeting in November last year reveal this:

para.inline: Sir James informed the Conference he had written to the previous government querying the omission of Reserve leave from the 20 allowable items in the Workplace Relations Act 1996, and discussed the response to his query. He stated that he was unhappy with the response and he intends to pursue the matter.

speech.para: You have to remember—Sir James Killen was a Liberal Government Minister for defence and this Government won't even listen to his advice.

When this Bill was recently presented in the other place, by the Hon Kim Beazley, Mr Beazley made the point that this issue should have been put to rest some years ago, when the Minister for Aged Care, the Hon Bronwyn Bishop was the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. She ignored the advice of Major General Luttrell, the then Assistant Chief of Defence Force Reserves who said to Minister Bishop:

para.inline: As Reserve members constitute approximately 40 per cent of the ADF work force, their continued availability for training, as currently provided for in awards, agreements and company personnel policies, is essential to the Australian Defence Force capability.

speech.para: Luttrel went on:

para.inline: If not identified as a matter for inclusion in awards, Reserve training leave may not be picked up within either the Certified Agreement, Australian Workplace Agreements or other State Agreements which will increasingly supplant existing awards.

Although not one of the safety net employment conditions identified in the Bill, Reserve availability for training is critical to maintaining defence capability and ward coverage of this issue is an important component of ensuring availability. The Bill should therefore include provisions which would permit awards to continue to cover Defence Force leave provisions.

speech.para: In February of 1998 Minister Bishop wrote to the Armed Force Federation saying:

para.inline: I am well aware of the threat to reserve training as a possible outcome of the Workplace Relations Act.

speech.para: She should have been, because the matter had been raised with her in the Parliament and with her senior minister a year earlier. So what has the Government done about that in the two years since this matter was first raised and the nearly three years now since its legislation created this problem? The simple fact is it has done nothing.
Labor have recognised that there is a problem, and have been willing to do something about it.

We have raised questions on notice and questions without notice, and received empty promises or no answer at all. My colleagues have introduced Private Members Bills in the other place. The Hon. Arch Bevis MP, Shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, introduced the Workplace Relations Amendment (Defence Purposes Leave) Bill 1999 on 21 June this year—but the Government didn't bring it on for debate.

As I mentioned, the Hon. Kim Beazley MP introduced this bill into the House of Representatives, as I am now doing here today. I hope, in the current climate, the Government will now allow debate on this issue and allow this bill to proceed. This bill will provide job security for those men and women who wish to undertake duty as an Australian Defence Force Reservist, and allow them to undertake the training they need to prepare them for the dangerous circumstances they may find themselves in. This will provide relief and respite to those Australians already serving in INTERFET.
As Mr Beazley said yesterday, `Now is critical. It is not going to be possible to sustain this deployment for any length of time without recourse to reserves.'
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Greig) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to give effect to the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Greig) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
In 1949 this Parliament commenced some business that fifty years later remains unfinished. That business was no less that the prohibition and punishment of the heinous crime of genocide.

In 1949, no doubt after some of the horrors of the Nazi Holocaust had become known, Australia ratified the Convention for the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide . It was a good and necessary thing to do, however fifty years down the track—the prevention and punishment of the crime of genocide remains unfinished business by the Commonwealth Parliament.
At the time of the introduction of the Bill, then member for Macquarie and LaborPrime Minister Ben Chifley had the following to say:

para.inline: The purpose of this Bill is to seek the approval of the Parliament for Australian ratification of the International Convention on the prevention and punishment of the Crime of Genocide. Genocide, which means the wholesale or partial destruction of religious, racial or national groups has long shocked the conscience of mankind.

speech.para: During the debate on the same Bill, the Leader of the Opposition and founder of the Liberal Party of Australia—Mr Menzies had this to say:

para.inline: Every member of this Parliament must view with equal horror the practice of mass killing and of persecution of people to the death, for the reasons of race or religion or for other reasons of the kind referred to in the convention. Of course the crime of genocide was not peculiar to Germany; I am not without my suspicions, nor are honourable members, that it is still going on in some parts of the civilized world, and for all I know may be going on in countries, one or more which are signatories to this convention.

speech.para: Mr Menzies went on to say:

para.inline: Persecution of the kind against which the convention is directed must never be tolerated . . . and I am perfectly certain that it will never be tolerated here.

However the last thing I should dream of doing would be to speak or vote in such a way as to cast any doubt on the proposition that in Australia we abominate the crime of genocide. No body has ever doubted it. If it needs our subscription to a convention to advertise our feelings to the world, then let us subscribe to it.

speech.para: Honourable Senators, it falls upon each generation to assert the basic minimum standards of humanity and upon every politician to uphold those standards. It is therefore out of a solemn sense of duty that I, as a representative of my generation, present this Bill for consideration by the Australian Senate.
Fifty years is a long time to have unfinished business and I would be pleased to be able stand here today and echo the words of Sir Robert Menzies and say that:

para.inline: Persecution of the kind against which the convention is directed must never be tolerated . . . and I am perfectly certain that it will never be tolerated here.

speech.para: However as recently as September this year, the Federal Court of Australia in the case of Nulyarimma v Thompson (1/9/99 Federal Court) confirmed that there was indeed no offence of genocide known in Australian law. While the details of this case are certain to be debated for many years to come—the one resounding message is clear—at this present time, genocide is not unlawful in Australia.

As this Bill is tabled in the Senate, news is emerging from our closest neighbours in East Timor of atrocities, war crimes and evidence of genocide. Indeed, before the United Nations last month, the Foreign Minister Mr Downer said:

para.inline: In the face of acts of genocide or of human rights abuses on a horrendous scale (in East Timor) the nations of the world must act.

speech.para: The Australian Democrats continue to endorse this Government's peace-keeping role in East Timor. However, as a nation we must, I believe, be active as well as reactive in the face of genocide. We must lead by example. This Bill provides that example.

Some people have suggested that it is unnecessary to legislate against the crime of genocide in Australia. They argue that the existing criminal laws at State and Territory level are sufficient protection against arbitrary and systemic persecution and murder. The Australian Democrats disagree. In those terms the convention clearly distinguishes the offence of genocide as a crime that is directed at a particular group. It is the membership of a group which distinguishes this crime.

It was the fact of being targeted on the grounds of religion, ethnicity, political affiliation, sexual orientation, gender or disability which previously has qualified people as targets for genocide and for no other reason.
I would like to turn now to what is meant by genocide
This convention defines genocide as follows:
Article II, stipulates that any of the following acts committed with the intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, and includes the:
(a) killing members of a group
(b) causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group
(c) deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about it's physical destruction in whole or in part
(d) imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group
(e) forcibly transferring children of the group to another group

Article III clarifies that not only is genocide a crime, so to is "conspiracy to commit genocide", "direct and public incitement to commit genocide", "attempt to commit genocide" and "complicity in genocide".

Honourable Senators—Genocide is as much a political crime as it is a crime against humanity. It is a crime which rests in the abuse of power by those who have power, against those who do not. As a political crime, it is as appropriate that in this Senate, in this Parliament and in this country that we as this generation of political leaders, stand side by side with the sentiments of Ben Chifley and Robert Menzies expressed fifty years ago.

The Bill to ratify Convention passed through this Parliament with multipartisan support in 1949. Indeed chief amongst its supporters was the father of the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley. At the time, Mr Kim Beazley senior said:

para.inline: Every person in Australia with red blood in his veins and a spirit of humanity in his heart should applaud the Minister for External Affairs (Dr Evatt) for supporting a Bill of this kind so soon after his return to Australia and for seeking the approval of the Australian Parliament to such a magnificent statement of this country's intentions to do all in its power to prevent the commission of the acts that are referred to in this convention.

speech.para: I signal here my intention to approach the Leader of the Opposition to seek his and his party's support to complete the work that his father helped start in 1949. I will also be writing to my Senate colleagues, the Prime Minister and members of the House of Representatives to seek their support. I look forward to their co-operation on this issue.

It is my intention that this Bill now be referred to the Senate's Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report to the Senate mid next year. Accordingly, I will be giving a notice of motion today. The reference of this Bill to the Senate's Legal and Constitutional References Committee will give members of the community the opportunity to comment upon the Bill and make suggestions for its improvement. I welcome this process and input, sincerely believing that the wider input of the Australian community is necessary to raise awareness of the issues surrounding genocide and to make this Bill Australia's best statement against this crime.

Comparative jurisdictions have implemented their obligations under the convention. The UK has implemented under its Genocide Act 1969 , and section 318 of the Canadian Criminal Code has implemented the convention to a more limited extent. The United States of America implemented legislation in 1988. Since then, there have been numerous calls for Australia to follow suit, most notably in the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law 1991, which stated:

para.inline: ". . . .the Australian Government decided in 1949 to limit Australian legislation to approve ratification. Whether there should be further Australian implementation or clarifying legislation was left in abeyance until the attitude of other contracting parties and action taken by other contracting parties as regards their domestic legislation was known.
The position of Australian law as regards to this convention, in the opinion of the review committee is clearly unsatisfactory."

speech.para: In closing I wish to dedicate this Bill and the ensuing Senate Committee inquiry that will follow to all those who have suffered the horrors of genocide. To the Jewish community, the Armenians, the Rawandans, Tibetans, Cambodians, Kosovars, East Timorese, non-Han ethnic Chinese, peoples of the former Yugoslavia, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, to people with disabilities, the gay and lesbian community and the many others who have suffered genocide, this Bill is introduced into the Senate in their memory and through the determination I have to see Australia lead by example in this regard.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I should make the point that, as these are both references to standing Senate committees, you did not actually need leave to move the notices of motion. You are capable of doing that at any stage.

—On behalf of the very hardworking parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works, I present the 10th report of 1999, entitled CSIRO Clayton (Eastern Precinct) development works, Victoria and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Madam President, the report which I have just tabled concerns the proposed construction of facilities at the CSIRO's Clayton site in Melbourne.

Research complexes at the Clayton site now house the largest concentration of CSIRO scientific expertise in Victoria. The site is the centre of CSIRO research into minerals, forest products, molecular and polymer science, manufacturing science and technology and mathematical and information science.

The proposal examined by the Committee will enable the consolidation of CSIRO's the Divisions of Manufacturing Science and Technology, Mathematics, Information Science, Information Technology Services and Petroleum Resources at Clayton.
This consolidation will enable CSIRO to vacate sites at Preston and Syndal, freeing up these sites for sale.
It will also relocate staff and resources from leased premises.

The extent of the proposal will provide nearly 7,000 square metres gross floor area of new building accommodation, together with another 7,000 square metres of refurbishment in an existing laboratory complex. The scope of the proposed works will provide laboratories, offices, process and technical bays, research support facilities and staff amenities.
It will provide modern scientific research facilities for over 370 staff.
When referred to the Committee, the estimated cost of the project was $28 million.
The Committee has recommended that the project should proceed.

In arriving at this recommendation, the Committee has concluded that since 1961, substantial investments have been made by the Commonwealth in the construction of major CSIRO research laboratory complexes at Clayton.

A number of elements of research Divisions, in particular Manufacturing Science and Technology and Petroleum Resources remain at other centres within the Melbourne metropolitan area in properties owned or leased by CSIRO.
Capacity remains at the Clayton site for further collocation and rationalisation of research activities.
This rationalisation would result in reduced overheads and realise proceeds from property sales for investment in new and upgraded research facilities at Clayton.

It would also facilitate interaction between research groups and between Divisions, cooperative research centres and staff and post-graduate students from Monash University which is located adjacent to the Clayton site.
In property terms, sites at Preston and Syndal and leased premises at Carlton and Clayton could be vacated and staff relocated to Clayton.
On this basis, the Committee concluded that a need therefore exists to provide additional research facilities at the Clayton site for more than 370 CSIRO staff.

The Committee has also concluded that the scope of the proposed development includes refurbished and new accommodation at a standard commensurate with modern research requirements and on a scale consistent with the number of staff to be employed.

The scope of the project can also be justified as making adaptive reuse of refurbished buildings with new construction reflecting contemporary generic research facilities already provided at other sites.
There is capacity for expansion.
Two matters need to be addressed by the CSIRO. First, the Committee has recommended that the need for stainless steel downpipes proposed for the refurbished David Rivett Building should be reviewed.
Secondly, the Committee has recommended that the CSIRO should develop a master plan for the further development of the site which will avoid costly removal of existing facilities and infrastructure.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

talk.start.para: —I present the 15th report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, entitled Interim report for the s.206(d) inquiry: proceedings of conference on 12 March 1999 .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

As chair of that committee, I am very happy to table today the committee's 15th annual report. This is an interim report which looks at the background to the very significant inquiry into section 206(d) of the Native Title Act. This report covers the proceedings of a conference which was held on 15 March this year to give background to the inquiry.

The inquiry covers a range of issues including, very importantly, the effectiveness of the National Native Title Tribunal, the operation of the Torres Strait Islander Land Fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation, the extent of the extinguishment or impairment of native title rights and interests as a result of the operation of the act and the effect of the operation of the act on land management.

The committee is consulting widely across the Australian community about the act, and the proceedings that are tabled today signify the start of this inquiry. The conference was most successful. It was well attended, with a range of participants from the Kimberley Land Council, the Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement, a number of government departments, ATSIC, the Minerals Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Native Title Tribunal and of course the Indigenous Land Corporation.

The contribution of all those participants was of great assistance in identifying issues of concern to the inquiry. We have already conducted a number of public hearings in this regard. In Western Australia we have been to Broome, Kununurra, Kalgoorlie and Perth. We have been up in the regional areas of Queensland, including Mount Isa. In coming months the committee will also be conducting public hearings in South Australia and in the Torres Strait as part of this inquiry.

This report contains information which is of great importance. In addition to being informative on past developments, the 15th report also foreshadows some of the major issues that will be the focus of the committee's consideration in the course of the section 206(d) inquiry. For example, chapters 2 and 8 summarise the history and function of two important institutional bodies: the Native Title Tribunal and the Indigenous Land Corporation. In chapter 2, which looks at the effectiveness of the Native Title Tribunal, the report notes that the assessment of the tribunal's effectiveness must focus on the core function of the tribunal, which is now mediation.

In chapter 7 the report provides an overview of the issues for land management which were brought about by the recognition of native title at common law within Australia. Included in this chapter is a useful summary of the future act regime of the Native Title Act, both in its original form and also after amendment, and of the provisions which deal with the indigenous land use agreements which were added in the amendments of 1998 and are now proving to be very successful in resolving issues involving native title.

The committee is carefully considering the effectiveness of the indigenous land use provisions of the act in resolving issues related to future acts. This section 206(d) inquiry is the most important and wide ranging to be conducted by the committee. It is essentially an inquiry into the effectiveness and consequences of the major features of the Native Title Act and the impact of the act on land ownership and the management of it from both an indigenous and non-indigenous perspective.

The information contained in the 15th report is an important starting point for the committee's current inquiry. It will also be useful and informative for any person who is interested in this area of law and in the committee's current inquiry. I commend the 15th report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.
