talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to report to the Senate on the rapidly changing situation with BHP steelworks in Newcastle. Last time I spoke we were then right on the cusp of the shutdown of the smelting operations in Newcastle. I did indicate at that time that BHP was now just a small player in the Hunter economy—this was before smelting was shut down. It was at that time employing one per cent of the work force. It was only the third largest employer, following the Hunter Area Health Service and the university. I would like to emphasise yet again—because this message seems to have been lost across Australia and indeed the world—that we were not shutting down steel production in Newcastle; just smelting. We were still employing 1,100 people in the rolling of steel and if you add in Tubemakers—a subsidiary of BHP—which then uses that product, another 600 again. There are still 1,700 steelworkers in Newcastle in the rod, bar and wire divisions and Tubemakers.

speech.para: When smelting shut down, 2,100 people were case managed by BHP in five streams through their very successful Job Pathways program. Twenty-five million dollars was injected by BHP, by the New South Wales government and the federal government to assist in the process of moving people who were losing their jobs onto one of these five pathways. At the end of this process, when it comes to looking at how many people are going to have some difficulty finding work, we come down to a figure of 600 direct employees and 100 subcontractors—a total of 700.

Since I made my last matter of public interest speech on this matter, the shutdown has actually occurred. The press really tried to turn this into a bad news story and failed dismally. I was on Sky News, and they were carrying international images of the steelworks, my voiceover and funeral music in the background. But the image on the day was very different as steelmaking in Newcastle was shut down. The image on the day was of the workers coming out of the gate in quite a happy mood—almost a party mood. You must ask, `Why not?' For some of them who had put in 22 years of service in the steel industry, they were walking out with superannuation plus $80,000 in severance pay. This of course is a great financial boost to the Hunter economy.

The mood of the day was best captured on the Channel 9 news report that night. A reporter, obviously trying to get a bad news story, went up to one of the workers and asked, `Where to for you now?' and the worker said, `The Phoenix Club, mate, and it's your shout!' That sort of positive response helped kill the bad news story. BHP are to be congratulated on the management of this process. With such a good outcome, it is obviously an example of world best practice in the management of the downsizing of a work force.

It is a great pity that BHP did not give the same degree of thought or put the same effort into developing similar processes when they moved on to the next stage last week. They hardly let the people of Newcastle catch their breath before they announced, within one week of the shutdown, that they were going to sell off quite a considerable number of their steel assets. They are retaining some steel business. They plan to retain the Port Kembla steelworks, Coated Steel Australia and Asia, Steel Building Products Australia, New Zealand Steel and Steel Building Products Asia. These businesses employ 13,500 people, and they are part of the retained portfolio of BHP. They are divesting the Long Products Division, which is mainly based in Newcastle but has a number of other centres around Australia; Tubemakers; Structural and Pipelines Products; tin mills; Coated Steel Corporation USA; Steel Building Products USA/Pacific; and North Star. There are approximately 9,000 employees there.

When BHP made this announcement, they gave the civic leaders of Newcastle some warning and did call a number of us in to explain what they were doing. I expressed disappointment that they had made the announcement at a time when they did not have a definite buyer, thereby creating uncertainty, and that they were not prepared to stay in a comprehensive steel industry.

Over the last 15 years BHP have upgraded the Port Kembla steelworks. It is now the third most efficient integrated steelworks in the world. They closed down the ageing smelter in Newcastle and they still have a comparative advantage in Whyalla, with high-grade, quality ore and at least 15 years supply of ore close to the mill. Those three elements I have just mentioned provide the ingredients to rebuild a world-class, comprehensive steel industry. Unfortunately, with that sort of opportunity BHP seem to have lost the will to do that. Of course it is a commercial decision, and BHP have made that decision in the context of a global steel industry—and they have every right to make that decision. They face intense competition worldwide; falling prices; increasingly demanding customer needs; the emergence of new low capital intensive technologies, particularly arc furnace technology; and the need for a relentless focus on cost reduction. The government cannot change that.

Kevin Maher, the head of the Ironworkers Union in the city, expressed the hope that the next buyer will be more committed to the steel industry. The good news is that BHP does not plan to shut down any of these businesses. What it plans to do is to sell them off. Announcing these initiatives on 6 October, the President of BHP Steel, Bob Every, said:

These changes give effect to the strategic objective of building on the company's strong position in minerals, while taking advantage of niche opportunities in steel. They are an essential part of BHP's evolution if it is to remain a global player.

These changes are not about closing businesses. They aim to focus BHP on operations that are consistent with portfolio objectives and to allow other companies, with different objectives, to bid for businesses that no longer fit the BHP portfolio.

The reason for the loss of will on steel by BHP is to be found in a speech to the Australian Investment Conference by the Managing Director and CEO of BHP, Paul Anderson. The speech was peppered with phrases like `It will be a company focused on creating value for shareholders', `Focus on these activities that will accelerate growth in shareholder value', `We will continue to reduce employee numbers and strive for efficiency', `Cost will be king', `The response to globalisation is mega consolidation', and `BHP will be a natural resource company with a steel component'.

This shows the driving force behind BHP's quite proper commercial decision. However, I feel that the founders of BHP, Guillaume Delprat and Essington Lewis, would be turning in their graves. They had a vision and they built, through the first half of this century, a vast industrial conglomerate, starting with minerals and then moving into mining and manufacturing. One hundred years later, BHP, the Big Australian, is shrinking back towards its beginnings.

If the new investors had lifted their vision above the short-term bottom line, they could have reignited that original vision. I hold hope that their limited vision of a company with a narrow base does not create long-term value problems for their shareholders. I also hope that their move away from a comprehensive steel industry, which in the future may not include high-tensile rod and bar products, does not create long-term strategic difficulties for Australia. The founders of BHP Steel, Delprat and Lewis, understood its strategic value when they built a comprehensive steel industry between World War I and World War II. It is a pity that this vision has been lost with the passage of time.

subdebateinfo.title: University of Western Sydney: Higher Education Research Funding

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the likely impact of changes to higher education research funding, proposed in the government's green paper on higher education research and research training entitled `New knowledge, new opportunities'. It is with concern that I rise to illustrate some of the potentially damaging consequences for Greater Western Sydney that will result from the implementation of the government's green paper. As a local resident and a duty senator for Western Sydney, I am particularly concerned that the proposed changes will inevitably have a detrimental impact upon one of the most significant institutions in the Greater Western Sydney region—that is, the University of Western Sydney.

speech.para: What seems to be clear from the green paper is the fact that the proposed changes to the funding formulae will lead to inequitable outcomes for universities such as the University of Western Sydney and will have a direct impact upon the Greater Western Sydney region. The bias in favour of the established `sandstone' institutions, contained within the funding formulae proposed in the green paper, seems to deny the valuable research role that emerging universities like UWS can play. As a relatively young university, UWS has distinguished itself as an educational and research centre of excellence and has achieved much for the people of Greater Western Sydney. It has brought high quality educational opportunities to the doorstep of one of the most dynamic, diverse and burgeoning population centres in Australia.

By all available measures, the University of Western Sydney has proven itself to be the leader of the non-technology, post-1987 universities. Some of the university's most significant advances in recent times have come as a result of its investment in developing a rapidly expanding research base. In recent times, the university has aggressively sought to attract increased external research income, with the result being a threefold increase in external research income in what is a highly competitive market. At the same time, postgraduate research completions have increased from zero in 1993 to 63 in 1998, with a 30 per cent increase in postgraduate students since 1995.

In actively seeking to develop its research base, the university has worked hand in hand with local industry. With 103 funded research partnerships with organisations in Greater Western Sydney and a tenfold increase in industrial research funds since 1995, the UWS research programs have become a showcase of what can be achieved when universities, local business, local government and local communities forge strategic partnerships. But, sadly, much of this fine work will be brought undone if the government proceeds with the recommendations of Dr Kemp's green paper. It is estimated that the reforms outlined in the green paper will have the net effect of reducing funding to UWS by at least $2.35 million per annum, or $7 million over the next triennium, with a corresponding reduction in postgraduate research places of up to 77 per cent in the second year of the reforms. In dismantling the university's fledgling research base, these reforms will ensure that the university will return to being just a purely teaching institution rather than an innovative centre of academic research and excellence.

If implemented, the recommendations of the green paper will have a crippling effect upon the university and almost certainly upon the people of Greater Western Sydney. It is important to recall precisely why the Labor Party established the UWS in the first place. It was the Labor Party that created the UWS to expand educational opportunities for the people of Western Sydney. But if the proposals contained within the green paper are implemented, we will see those educational opportunities, particularly postgraduate opportunities, for the people of Greater Western Sydney diminished. These changes will deny the people of Western Sydney the opportunity to pursue an advanced education in close proximity to where they live and work. But the impact of these changes extends beyond the direct effect of the reduction in postgraduate places and an overall reduction in research funding.

Not only will these changes devastate the university's research base and close off educational opportunities for the people in Western Sydney; they will have a profoundly negative impact upon the communities surrounding these campuses. In areas such as Penrith, Campbelltown and Parramatta, local employment opportunities, the success of small businesses and the viability of developing industries will be jeopardised by the green paper's proposals. To proceed with the recommendations of the green paper will be to rip away the very foundations of accessible education in Sydney's west. After spending the last decade taking on the more established institutions and succeeding in a very difficult area of research and research training, the UWS is now being told by the government that it should not be in the business of developing a research base.

All this comes at a time when the government is mouthing the rhetoric of the `knowledge nation' and the need to invest in the knowledge based sectors of the economy. Here we have an example of where a university has succeeded in bringing together academia and industry in strategic alliances that have provided enormous benefits to local communities; however, the government now seems committed to bringing an end to success stories such as this. It seems to me that the government believes in the benefits of the knowledge based economy, but not for Western Sydney. It is true that these are only recommendations emerging from the green paper and that there will be a number of opportunities for the government to see sense on this issue. I must, however, express my complete lack of faith in the government when it comes to the likelihood of a policy outcome on this issue. To this point in time, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, has refused to even meet with representatives of UWS to discuss in detail the impact of these proposed changes.

Given revelations about the minister's vision for higher education aired in the House of Representatives earlier today with the release of his cabinet submission, I have even less faith in the minister. A matter of even more concern is the complete lack of action of a number of the local representatives of the areas most affected by these changes. The two most affected areas include the electorates of Parramatta and Lindsay. Whilst representatives of the university have had the opportunity to meet both these members, neither of these members has taken up the issue with the degree of vigour that one would expect, given the profoundly detrimental impact that these changes will have on the people of the Parramatta and Penrith communities.

Whilst the member for Parramatta has chosen to ignore the issue, the member for Lindsay has hardly been convincing in her support for the cause of the university. If the member for Parramatta could reduce his point of order load to only one per sitting day, I am certain he would be better able to utilise his time representing the legitimate concerns of his local community.

Similarly, far from providing this critical local issue with her wholehearted and unequivocal support, the member for Lindsay is reported in the local newspapers as saying, `It's important all possible views are heard—that's why I will ensure the relevant material will be considered by the right people.' Well, the people of Lindsay deserve much better from their local member. These proposed changes will cause irreparable damage to their local community, will adversely affect employment levels and will provide an additional barrier to participation in higher education for people in her electorate—and the best that the member for Lindsay can do is to say that she will make sure that the university's submission is heard by the right people.

The people of Lindsay deserve more than a delivery service from their local member. They deserve a local member who will recognise that these proposals will be damaging to their community, and they deserve a member who will roll up her sleeves and fight for them. If the people of Parramatta and Lindsay cannot rely upon their local members to fight for their interests, who can they count on? Mr Acting Deputy President, I can assure you that the Labor Party will be fighting for their interests, because we will not let this government destroy UWS. We have fought too hard for educational opportunities for people in Greater Western Sydney to stand by and allow this ideologically driven government to dismantle an institution that is so critical to the prosperity of Greater Western Sydney.

If Mr Kemp wants to deprive Western Sydney of access to education—and research funding to the University of Western Sydney is the battleground—then I can assure you that the Labor Party will defend the interests of the west, with or without the assistance of its local members.

subdebateinfo.title: New South Wales National Party: 80th Anniversary

talk.start.para: —The New South Wales National Party today marks its 80th anniversary as a political organisation. In the late 1800s and early 1900s there was a growing dissatisfaction that political parties of the day were ignoring the issues of concern to all but those living in the metropolitan areas. We were formed as a progressive party by the establishment of a central electoral council at a meeting in Sydney on 13 October 1919 of representatives of the Farmers and Settlers Association of New South Wales, the Graziers Association of New South Wales and the People's Party of Soldiers and Citizens. We subsequently became the Country Party in 1925.

speech.para: The party has been continuously and strongly represented in the New South Wales and federal parliaments since its inception and has a proud record of achievement for its constituents in non-metropolitan areas. It is a record upon which we continue to build today. Over the years, many doomsayers have predicted the end of the Country Party, yet we remain strong, independent and proud. We continue to boast the largest membership of any political organisation in Australia.

The federal National Party will mark its 80th anniversary on 22 January next year. The strength of our history is a fundamental foundation that will ensure our continuing independent future. I pay tribute to all past and present members and supporters who have bound together to make us the great and enduring organisation that we are. On behalf of all my National Party colleagues—and, I am sure, all the members of this chamber—I wish the National Party of New South Wales many more successful anniversaries.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about a very important issue in the area of aged care—that is, the findings of the Productivity Commission's report into nursing home subsidies. I must start by saying that the Democrats are very disappointed at the coalition's lack of response to the findings of this important inquiry. We had hoped that, in line with the stated commitment to improving the provision of aged care services, the government would have taken the findings of this inquiry much more seriously than it seems to have done. Not only has the government not responded but, despite receiving the findings of this inquiry in January this year, it has failed to give any indication as to when it will be responding.

speech.para: As I said recently in my second reading contribution on the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 , the Democrats believe that this is most unsatisfactory. It is yet another example of a government setting up its own objective independent body to look into what needs to be done in the area of aged care, only to ignore its findings—reminiscent, perhaps, of the way that the ALP ignored the recommendations contained in its Gregory report when it was in government, which the Democrats, amongst others, rightly condemned the now opposition for.

The coalition's failure to respond to the Productivity Commission's report on nursing home subsidies has left those with an interest in aged care with little option but to ask ourselves whether this is really just history repeating itself. The minister has said time and time again that the government will be providing a whole of government response to the findings of the Productivity Commission's inquiry into nursing home subsidies, and that it will be made public in due course. However, despite these findings being released in January this year, we still have no idea when this whole of government response will be forthcoming.

Prior to the last federal election, there was considerable concern about the government's policy of coalescence in relation to nursing home subsidies. This policy will involve a reduction in subsidies for residents in nursing homes in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and the Northern Territory in order to provide more equitable subsidies to nursing home residents in the lower funded states of Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the ACT.

The Democrats were therefore very pleased when the government referred the matter of nursing home subsidies for independent investigation by the Productivity Commission. In announcing this inquiry, the then Minister for Aged Care, Warwick Smith, said:
The Government gives the commitment to all Australians that it will consider and respond to whatever the Productivity Commission finds.

The Productivity Commission consulted widely and after extensive consideration of the issues presented its recommendations to the government on 13 January this year. On receiving these recommendations, the government issued a press release saying:
The report endorses the government's intention to move towards uniform national subsidies for residential aged care.

Well, not quite, as it turns out. Anyone who has read the findings of this report will be able to attest that this claim is a very creative interpretation of the facts. It is a very creative interpretation of the facts because, rather than endorsing the policy of coalescence as the government has claimed, the Productivity Commission opposed it. It opposed the government's policy of coalescence because it is not based on a benchmark costing for a standard of care that would apply across Australia but simply on the average of current state subsidies. This is a very arbitrary kind of base with no real grounding in care standards.

What the Productivity Commission did recommend was a subsidy regime which provides a clear link to the standard of care which the Commonwealth is seeking and funding that is adequate to meet the cost of providing that benchmark standard of care. Based on the current variation in standardised costs among the states and territories, the commission drew attention to the inequitable underfunding of services in Queensland and South Australia and recommended that this be addressed as a matter of priority. The timing of the implementation of coalescence presents serious problems for the services. Equitable funding for Queensland and South Australia would not be achieved until 2004-05, making it very difficult for services in these states to achieve accreditation and operate viable services.

Urgent action is required if the government is not to be seen as placing a lower value on older people in these states and forcing aged care providers to eat into their capital reserves in order to maintain standards. Funding for services in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and the Northern Territory will be offset by eight per cent of the difference from the national average on 1 July 2000. The reduction in subsequent years increases to 14 per cent, 24 per cent, 24 per cent and 24 per cent respectively. Services will find it increasingly difficult to maintain quality of care under these arrangements.

A further recommendation of the commission was the introduction of revised indexation arrangements for nursing home subsidies as soon as possible. It found that there was an urgent need for special needs funding in high cost areas such as rural and remote areas to ensure that these older Australians needing care were not disadvantaged.

The whole point of the Productivity Commission inquiry into nursing home subsidies was to determine whether the proposed coalescence of nursing home subsidies should proceed or be replaced by another funding methodology. Yet despite the fact that the inquiry did not endorse the government's coalescence proposal in setting nursing home subsidy rates from June this year, the government went ahead with its proposal anyway. This is causing ongoing difficulties for many aged care providers, particularly in those states which currently receive a disproportionately low level of funding—South Australia and Queensland.

At my request, leading peak bodies in the aged care sector recently met with me to discuss this issue. As a result of this meeting I can report that there is widespread support for the Productivity Commission's recommendations accompanied by a widespread concern at the government's failure to respond to those findings. The Democrats call on the government to end the current angst in the aged care sector by making it very clear exactly when and how the findings of this report will be responded to.

On International Older Persons Day the minister said that perhaps Australia doesn't value its older citizens enough. Surely this government does not wish to be condemned as devaluing older people through its inaction on the Productivity Commission recommendations. I therefore have no doubt that during this session we can work together to ensure that timely and appropriate action is taken on this matter so as to promote the wellbeing of frail older Australians and to demonstrate that they are truly valued by this government.

subdebateinfo.title: New South Wales National Party: 80th Anniversary

talk.start.para: —Just a brief moment following Senator Brownhill's acknowledgment of the 80th birthday of the National Party of New South Wales. My colleague Senator Tambling and I wish the National Party a happy birthday and, across the chamber, would you wish us a happy birthday too?
—Happy birthday.
—Thank you very much. And the Democrats? Before you leave the chamber, Senator Allison, do you wish us a happy birthday?
—I would love to sing to you.

—No, please don't. We are the second oldest party next to the Labor Party, which is significant in that we have stayed the test of time. We are not socialists; we have always condemned socialism. Nevertheless, we did grow out of a need to represent the rural and regional areas and did support the statutory marketing authorities. That was very much the hallmark of the National Party, our philosophy base. Much has changed since then—for some of us, to our regret. Statutory marketing is a fair and fine philosophy which seemingly time has passed by for, in some cases, good economic reasons. But let us not get bogged down in that. This is just a jump up to wish the National Party happy birthday.

speech.para: It could be interesting for those here to know that on average the National Party has held some 14 per cent of the parliament. We are not far from that these days. That is our natural position in the House of Representatives. For the federal party it is 80 years in January. We wish the New South Wales party its 80th birthday. The demographics, the seats, the voting system have changed. We now have one vote one value, where once there was a weighting towards the country people in electorates. That is a good thing and it would not hurt the parliament in celebrating our birthday to reconsider that.

You must remember that country people feel disenfranchised. One of the reasons is that they do not have the same political power as they used to because once there was an acknowledgment of the great distances out in the country regions and electorates were weighted accordingly. Now you have these massive electorates which National Party members have to service because of one vote one value. The servicing of that ideal has become an enormous burden and to a great extent those voters have become disenfranchised—another issue for another day.

Again, I wish the New South Wales party a happy birthday. They have dominated the National Party in that time. Most of our leaders have come from New South Wales—our existing leader, our previous leader, the leader before that, and so it goes on. I would have to say our best leader came from Victoria, the most notable leader, Jack McEwen. When we reach our federal birthday in January, I am told, it is to be a knees-up affair and all are invited.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 23 August 1999:

question.para: (1) In the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years, how many on-shore applications has the department received from individuals claiming refugee status.
(2) What has been the longest time frame taken to finalise any such claims.
(3) What has been the shortest time frame taken to finalise any such claims.
(4) Can the department quantify the cost of such claims to the Commonwealth; if so, what is the department's estimate of the cost of these claims over the above two financial years.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In 1997-98, 8,128 applications for protection visas were lodged on-shore with the department and 8,257 were lodged in 1998-99.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs Preparation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1413)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 September 1999.

question.para: With reference to the effect of the goods and services tax (GST) on the internal operations of the Minister's portfolio (that is, not relating to the services provided to the public), and in relation to each of the agencies within the portfolio:
(1) What preparations have been undertaken to date in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.
(2) (a) What has been the total cost of those actions already undertaken; and
(b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(3) Was the cost of undertaking this work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(4) What future preparations are planned or expected to be required in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(5) (a) What is the total cost of the actions planned, or the estimated cost of expected actions; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(6) Was the estimated cost of undertaking this future work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(7) Is there expected to be any change in the ongoing running costs of the department/agency after the commencement of the GST; if so, what is the extent of the difference in costs.
(8) Are there any other GST-associated costs which the portfolio agencies will incur prior to the commencement of the GST; if so, what are those costs.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A GST implementation plan has been developed and work is under way in the Department on progressing the various tasks under the plan to achieve GST readiness by 1 July 2000.
(2) The costs of actions already taken involve mainly the costs of staff who have been seconded to the departmental implementation team. The cost to date is $35000.

(3) No costs were included the Department's 1999-2000 allocation for the implementation of GST and no additional funds have been allocated for this purpose. As a result, costs are being met from existing allocations.
(4) The future actions planned or expected to be required for the introduction of GST in the Department include:
. Progression of implementation tasks under the plan;
. Staff training and awareness; and
. Implementation and testing of system enhancements.
(5) The estimated cost of the future actions planned is as follows:
- Consultancies/IT enhancements—$700,000
- Extra Staff—$210,000
- Staff Training—$20,000
(6) See (3) above.
(7) Apart from some savings arising from the abolition of wholesale sales tax, the impact of which has not yet been estimated, there is not expected to be any change to DETYA's running costs.
(8) See (3) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Preparation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1419)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 2 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the effect of the goods and services tax (GST) on the internal operations of the Minister's portfolio (that is, not relating to the services provided to the public), and in relation to each of the agencies within the portfolio:
(1) (a) What preparations have been undertaken to date in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(2) (a) What has been the total cost of those actions already undertaken; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(3) Was the cost of undertaking this work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(4) What future preparations are planned or expected to be required in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(5) (a) What is the total cost of the actions planned, or the estimated cost of expected actions; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(6) Was the estimated cost of undertaking this future work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(7) Is there expected to be any change in the ongoing running costs of the department/agency after the commencement of the GST; if so, what is the extent of the difference in costs.
(8) Are there any other GST-associated costs which the portfolio agencies will incur prior to the commencement of the GST; if so, what are those costs.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is currently preparing a taxation reform implementation plan. The implementation plan will identify the various tasks that will need to be completed in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.
(2) No discreet expenditure has been made so far on GST implementation.
(3) No additional funds were allocated in the 1999-2000 budget for GST implementation. The Commission will meet these costs from its existing budget as part of its operating costs.
(4) The Commission is currently preparing a comprehensive taxation reform implementation plan. This plan will review amongst other issues the following:
. accounting systems;
. staff training;
. Government grants;
. cash flow management; and
. compliance issues.

(5) (a) At this stage it is not possible to estimate the cost of actions planned as the implementation plan has not been finalised. It is likely that external consultants will be used to assist with implementation. (b) (i)—(vi) see (a).
(6) No additional funds were allocated in the 1999-2000 budget for GST implementation. The Commission will meet these costs from its existing budget as part of its operating costs.
(7) No estimate is available at this stage on the likely changes to ongoing running costs of the Commission.
(8) No estimate is available at this stage on other GST associated costs, which ATSIC will incur prior to the commencement of the GST.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the entry of plutonium cargo ships into Australian waters on 28 August 1999.
(1) Which organisation in Australia was initially notified that an emergency medical evacuation was necessary.
(2) How much time elapsed between this notification and the evacuation.
(3) Can details be provided of the accident and injuries sustained that necessitated the evacuation.
(4) (a) From which ship was the evacuation made; (b) what was the exact position of the ships; and (c) what was the time of the evacuation.
(5) Did both ships proceed to the evacuation point.
(6) (a) What type of aircraft carried out the evacuation; and (b) was it a commercial or Australian navy aircraft.
(7) For how long were the ships in Australia's exclusive economic zone (EEZ).
(8) What was the occupation of the evacuee on board the ship.
(9) Was the evacuee replaced.

(10) (a) Apart from the Federal Government and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, which other governments and organisations were notified of the entry of the Pacific Nuclear Transport Limited (PNTL) ships into Australia's EEZ and the medical evacuation; (b) was the State Government of Western Australia notified; and (c) was this notification provided before or after the ships entered the EEZ.
(11) Was British Nuclear Fuels Limited (BNFL) or the British Government consulted about the details of the evacuation.
(12) Who bore the cost of the evacuation.
(13) (a) What kind of accident on board a PNTL vessel would trigger the involvement of a BNFL emergency team; and (b) are there agreed criteria for this or is it determined on a case by case basis.
(14) If there was an accident on board a PNTL vessel involving the release or suspected release of radioactive materials, would the Australian Government provide assistance to the ship.
(15) (a) Which organisations in Australia, military or civilian, have the necessary expertise and equipment to deal with a radiological emergency; and (b) where are they based.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Department informed the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA), the organisation responsible for Search and Rescue operations.
(2) Seven days.
(3) AMSA has advised that the crew member fell in heavy sea conditions and injured his shoulder.

(4) (a) The ship's name is "Pacific Pintail"; (b) AMSA has advised that the "medevac" took place at sea 110 nautical miles off the Western Australian coast (south of Albany); (c) AMSA has advised that the "medevac" was successfully undertaken at 1015am AEST.
(5) Yes.
(6) (a) The "medevac" was undertaken by a helicopter; (b) Commercial.
(7) Between 24 and 30 hours.
(8) AMSA has advised that the injured person is an officer of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Constabulary.

(10) (a) No other government or organisation was notified of entry of the ships into the EEZ, which is not a relevant boundary in the context of the medevac or the innocent passage of the ships. BNFL notified the Ship's Agent in Australia of the medevac, who in turn notified Australian Customs. AMSA notified the WA Police of the time and position of the impending medevac, and the intended movements of the Medevac helicopter; (b) AMSA informed the WA State Police of the medevac; (c) AMSA estimates that the WA Police were notified around the time the ships would have been expected to have entered the EEZ. The precise time that the ships entered the EEZ is not known.
(11) BNFL provided a specialist adviser in Perth to assist AMSA in arranging the medevac. The British High Commission was involved throughout.
(12) AMSA has confirmed that BNFL paid the costs of the medical evacuation.
(13) This question should be referred to BNFL.
(14) Any request for assistance would depend on the nature of the incident and take account of Australia's international obligations.

(15) (a) Emergency Management Australia (EMA), Department of Defence has advised that States and Territories are responsible for emergency management, including radiological emergencies. In the event that they require Commonwealth assistance they can request such assistance in accordance with the Commonwealth Government Disaster Response Plan (COMDISPLAN). In the unlikely event of a radiological emergency, assistance could be provided from the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA). Both organisations have personnel trained and equipped to assist in the event of a radiological emergency. The Australian Defence Force also maintains a small group of specialists which could assist in a radiological emergency. (b) ANSTO is located at Lucas Heights near Sydney; ARPANSA is located in Melbourne; and the School of Military engineering is located at Moorebank in Sydney.

subdebateinfo.title: Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Pension: Recipients
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1547)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) How many Australian service personnel who saw service between 1972 and 1994 have been
granted a Totally and Permanently Incapacitated (TPI) pension.
(2) How many of the above TPI recipients saw service entirely within Australia.
(3) How many of the above TPI recipients were enlisted during the Vietnam conflict but did not see service outside Australia.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) 3,328 (2,586 of these individuals have had service outside Australia in conflicts prior to 1972 such as Vietnam, the Far East Strategic Reserve and Korea, or in deployments since 1972 including Namibia, Somalia, Cambodia and the Persian Gulf. Their pensionable disabilities may have arisen from their peacetime service, overseas service or both. The remaining 842 have service only within Australia.)

(3) I am unable to answer this, as my Department's database does not require the date of enlistment to be recorded. Only the period of service which entitles ex-service personnel for compensation coverage under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 is recorded. Under the Act peacetime service, ie service within Australia, did not attract benefits until 7 December 1972.
